name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
description: Guide two brothers on an epic fairy tale journey from visionary Swedish film director, Josef Fares and top-tier developer Starbreeze Studios. Control both brothers at once as you experience co-op play in single player mode, like never before.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3 Processor: 2.4 GHz Dual Core Processor Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 8600 /ATI Radeon HD 2600 DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 2 GB available space Additional Notes: Initial installation requires one-time internet connection for Steam authentication; software installations required (included with the game) include Steam Client, DirectX 9, Microsoft .NET 4 Framework, Visual C++ Redistributable 2010, and AMD CPU Drivers (XP Only/AMD Only)

reviews.review_text: It's been a while since I played a game that's this lovingly crafted and that felt like it came from such a strong emotional space that exudes throughout the entire journey. Brothers is a game that deals with many different themes, some fantastical in nature, and tackles them head on and with a touch of nuance. It's also a very charming game that overcomes any technical limitation through great art direction.  Its basic concept of controlling the older brother on the left analog stick and the younger brother on the right is one that may turn off some at first but truly comes into its own as the game progresses with a thematic payoff unlike anything I've ever seen in a game before. Brothers also has excellent pacing that carries over into its puzzles. They are simple yet I never felt like they were braindead easy. They're always fresh in some way and play off of mechanics I learned before without ever showing a tutorial on screen outside of the beginning chapter.  Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons was an excellently developed puzzle platformer that wasn't afraid to go to some dark places but also knew when to highlight a truly joyous moment. And this was all through gameplay. These special moments or sections were rarely shown through cutscenes only. It wants you to experience these parts through gameplay as much as possible, and it very much succeeds at that. But it's a climactic moment near the end that truly brings that idea home. A moment so brilliant and emotionally resonant to me that it'd be a shame if people missed out on this because we're on the cusp of a new console generation transition. Don't pass this game up. It begs to be played.

Breathtakingly beautiful backgrounds, simple-enough puzzles that are still satisfying to solve, and a truly touching story that not only uses no words to tell it but makes the controls an integral part, adding extra gravitas at just the right moments.  And yes, I did shed a few tears.  Video games can be art when they're made to be and when it's done right. This game is definitive proof, and worth every penny despite the fairly short ~3 hour playtime.
My nomination for the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award  5 tears/5

I don't know what should I tell about this game that wasn't already told. You control the two brothers with a controller's two bumpers, or with wasd + arrows. Despite the game states that it requires a controller to play, it actually works fine with keyboard. The game is just wonderful, and keeps you at the edge of the seat - there's only a few sections where timing counts, most of the time you can keep your own pace, but as you'll pass hills, caverns, mountains there's always something to concentrate on. Most of the time it's the brand new ideas the game presents - the store's screenshots are from the game's first (maybe) 2 chapters, most of the game's content is pretty different and presents you with new experiences. You always have to pay attention to the movement if you're playing alone, but it's not overbearing, and it doesn't require pinpoint accuracy. The biggest challenge of the game is to not to mix up your two hands and which one controls witch brother :) While all you have is direction keys and an action button, this game is nowhere near an average walking simulator. The landscape goes though incredible changes as you progress, and you have various means of transportation that are both unique and makes excellent use of the game's control scheme. This game is a beautiful, albeit short journey which in turn has absolutely minimal downtime. It's a great purchase or it makes an excellent gift for anyone who's willing to try out the game's controls and loves traditional tales, as the game takes place in a similar world. The game contains darker tones, it's not really a kid-friendly game - the Teen rating is fitting in my opinion.

Brothers  is a deceptively simple puzzle platformer that has quite a bit going on under the covers. Its story is told almost entirely wordlessly, with a lot of little side excursions that paint a world of fairytales that is actually quite dark. Don't let the bright graphics and cartoony characters fool you -- while there are some funny and uplifting moments, this is not a feel good game. It's not deliberately out to depress you either, but it's more brothers Grimm than brothers Warner. I'm not saying you shouldn't let your kids play it, but I am saying you may want to look over their shoulder if they do.  Believe it or not, this is the game I bought a controller for. I borrowed one to see if the game was any good (it was) and then I completed it after buying one for myself. It's not easy to convince a hardcore mouse and keyboard guy to twiddle the sticks, so it deserves credit at least for that. It deserves some more credit for possibly being the very first game to use its control scheme to evoke an emotional response. I can't get into details (spoilers!) but you'll know it when you get there. It's beautifully done, and you'd need to have a heart of stone not to be at least a little bit affected. If you remember 'press F to pay respects', this is pretty much the exact opposite of that.  The gameplay is just about right. It's not very challenging, but it's not a cakewalk between cutscenes either. The game does make the most of its controls, and coordinating two characters requires your full attention. Liberal use of checkpoints means you're not likely to get frustrated from having to replay bits, though. If the game was much longer the mechanics might wear thin, but its length works to its advantage here. My only gripe, if I can have one, is that one or two achievements are almost impossible to obtain without a guide, not because they require skill but because they require some very unintuitive actions. Still, this in no way detracts from the experience on your first playthrough, and the game allows you to replay chapters at will, so those who want the achievements can get them easily enough.  Whether you want to pay the full $15 for 4-5 hours of game is up to you, but even if you want to wait for a sale (or another bundle), this deserves to be in your library at some point or another. Two thumbs up, one big and one little.

Great and short game, but very sad and heartbreaking. It says it requires a controller to play, but you can perfectly play it with the keyboard (although it can be stressful sometimes). That notice should say it's recommended, not required.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is nothing short of fantastic. The player controls both characters, where the player goes on an epic journey across all kinds different landscapes just to find a certain important object, which can save a certain someone. I don't want to give too much away b/c this game is absolutely epic, personal, and moving.   Brothers: ATOTS is basically a cross b/t a platformer, puzzle-game, and adventure game (like say a very-linear Tomb Raider game made before TR 2013) - but, there is absolutely no combat here what-so-ever. Brothers feels like it is something straight out of a classic fairy-tale or fable, drenched with tons of personality in its art direction & art design. It's nothing short of wonderful, with its excellent story-book look and feel. This couldn't have been done any better.  Most things here are not said to the player via dialogue or any sort of narration, they are shown to the player. There is no English dialogue - everything here is spoken in a language that sounds like its right out of The Sims' own Sim-language of gibberish. You come to conclusions, based on what you see on screen and how things are laid out and presented to you. Everything is meticulously placed, from the environments to characters - and a lot can be inferred given just how an area is laid out, how a character is placed, and whatnot. This kind of subtlety does remind me of how sometimes Dark Souls tells stories for namely those who are really playing attention, without even cracking one word of dialogue at times - except, this game never cracks one word of dialogue.   When played with a X360 controller (which is how I played this game), the player controls one brother w/ the left stick + interact w/ object w/ one of the left triggers, while the other brothers is controlled w/ the right stick + one of the right triggers. Nothing else I can think of feels like this, gameplay-wise. This feels extremely unique, in which you are basically playing a Co-Op style game...basically all by your lonesome self. It's genius and absolutely brilliant. You will need to control each brother at the right time sometimes; simultaneously sometimes (which can be confusing at first, and then joyous and awesome once you get the feel down correctly and execute a set-piece correctly); or do things in a certain manner to advance further in the game and story.   All of the set pieces here are fantastic and extremely well put together. From every story set-piece to every gameplay set-piece, everything is put together in such a manner in which it's integrated extremely well with each other. Each brother has their own advantages and disadvantages - one brother is much taller + stronger, while the other brother is smaller + skinnier. This can help lead players on how to figure out what to do in certain situations + encounters. Maybe the big brother needs to give the little brother a boost, so they can reach a ledge. Maybe the younger brother can squeeze through bars that his bigger brother can't get between. Thankfully, the puzzles aren't hard, obscure, or ridiculous - but the player likely will have a bunch of 'Aha!' moments, once the players realize how to make the brothers work together in the correct context and manner. Everything (difficulty-wise) is, as Goldilocks would say, 'just right.'  While it likely won't take players likely very long to finish, Brothers is an absolutely unforgettable journey that must be experienced. Players will be moved by this fantastic experience, once it reaches its jaw-dropping conclusion. Taking my time, it took me somewhere around 4-5 hours to finish. It is a delightful experience, every single solitary step of the way. This game should be experienced by every gamer and should not be missed. This story-book, fairytale-like, and fable-like experience here is brought to life absolutely beautifully.  Grade: A.

A clear 2013 Game of the Year candidate, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a third person puzzle game that gets absolutely everything right. The story is a simple one - your father needs help desperately, and you have to go find it. Throughout the journey you'll feel many emotions as you quickly grow attached to the brothers. This attachment is due to the fact that you control both brothers at the same time and you need to have them work together to fight through adversity and move on in your journey. The lack of lengthy cut-scenes and a made-up language were interesting choices that also worked 100% with this game. It makes you become even more involved, not just sit back and watch a movie play out in a game.  Graphics-wise, it's visually beautiful without the need of heavy tweaking. The game environment immerses you to its fantasy world instantly. Houses, farms, towns, cliffs, castles, mines, caves, water... all the environments are well-made and polished. The way you get to interact with animals in particular was phenomenal in my opinion. A lot of small interactions with people, items, and animals are not necessary to move on in your journey, but they add fun and depth to the game experience and gets you even more immersed.  It's recommended that you play with a controller, and I could see why. You control one brother with each joystick, and a lot of times you'll need to interact with both at exactly the same time to solve puzzles. I thought that the teamwork between the brothers was spectacular, and not something you see every day in a single player game. No gameplay bugs or annoyances to speak of. You just need to learn to work together with yourself :) The puzzles themselves are very simple, yet brilliant in how you go about to solving them.  All achievements are fun to attain, not a chore. If you missed an achievement during your first playthrough, you can go back and play each chapter separately. I finished the game in 4 hours. Others have finished it between 2 and 6 hours. The game was so much fun that I purposely had to put it down so that I didn't play through it in one sit-down.   I'm not going to spoil anything whatsoever regarding the story. All I'll say is that you'll experience many up's and down's throughout the journey. Which again, it's something that the game got 100% right. Right now I can't think of a single negative to speak of. I guess the game length would be the only negative since it's such a great and fun game that you'll wish the journey had lasted longer.  TotalBiscuit called Brothers the best game he's ever played, surpassing his previous choice (Deus Ex). I also happen to think that Deus Ex is one of, if not the best game ever made. I do understand why he would place Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons so high up the game ladder. I haven't played The Last of Us yet, but I would strongly make a case for Brothers as a 2013 Game of the Year candidate. I'm not a recognized game reviewer person or site, so it's just my humble opinion. But go ahead and buy Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons if you want a great, emotional gaming experience :)

This little gem is different than any games that I played, I'm enjoying it even I had a little bug at the beginning, couldn't rotate the handles by the bridge with My XBox, so I had to disconnect the XBox and use the Keyboard to get past that part, and I finally did, but it take longer and it's harder with the Keyboard, so when I finally got to a checkpoint, I could switch back to My Xbox. The lack of tutorials might be bothersome in the beginning, but makes the game much more immersive till the end. The soundtrack is illuminating as well. Has some replayability value too, though they could've included some more achievements. A must have in your library!

Brothers is a game where you control two brothers on a quest to save their father. The game is optomized with an Xbox 360 controller in mind, no doubt. Or at the very least, a controller. It can definitely be played with a keyboard and mouse, but I wouldn't recommend.  Now that I got that out of the way, I'll let you know why(if you didn't already know) this is one of the best games of the year. The way you control both brothers binds with the story so well its absolutely amazing. We all know when it comes to gaming there are two basic factors that make a video game: Mechanics and story. I think a game can have very little of one or the other, and still be a good game. However, it is extremely rare that the mechanics practically make the story. Its absolutely amazing how well it is done. I'm fairly sure its been done in similar ways before, but not in a way like this, in a way that makes the story what it is. The story wouldn't exist without the mechanics, its amazing how they flow.  There is no dialouge, yet the story is one of the best I've played. How the hell does that even happen? It completely took me by surprise. I didn't think that was possible until Journey, and now Brothers has done a very similar thing.   To be honest, while the mechanics do make the story, they don't come without bugs and issues. There were several times where the controls got in the way of me being able to complete a task. I don't entirely blame the game, I blame my brain for not always being able to keep track of both characters and coorespond that with the correct stick on the controller. Also, I ran into a few different glitches, but nothing broke my game. However I have heard of glitches forcing some people to restart entire chapters, which is not ideal.   I'm not going to tell you this is my favorite game of all time, or even my #1 game of the year, but that doesn't mean the game isn't amazing and plenty of fun. I would have been happy paying the full sale price, but at $4.49, its an absolute steal. Brothers gets my full recommendation. Buy it now(at this time it is 4.49) or at 14.99, it makes little difference. The game is absolutely worth every penny. Play Brothers today to experience one of the best blends of story and mechanics I've ever seen.     Buy At Full Price

A very short & bittersweet game that is full of heart and touching moments despite the fact that the language is intentionally made-up gibberish but the beauty of it all is that you can still understand what's going on without knowing what's being said. It is also one of the saddest games I've ever played. During the 3 or so hours that it will take you to complete the game you'll trek across picturesque landscapes filled with wonder and danger as you solve simple yet clever puzzles by controlling both brothers (use of a gamepad is strongly recommended). You'll also encounter a lonely and sad troll-like being who helps you navigate the environment and whom in turn you help by rescuing his captured mate. At another point you can stop a heartbroken man from commiting suicide and help him to come to terms with the death of his loved ones. It's no wonder that the game won Best Xbox Game at the VGX 2013 awards :)  9/10
Such a beautiful game cannot be described with words. A must buy.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is one of the best examples of a small game with big heart. It looks beautiful and plays surprisingly fun, thanks to the unprecedented control scheme that immerse us to simple yet entertaining platforming and puzzle mechanics, and some engraving sequences along the way.  More importantly it is an impressive and unforgettable journey. A journey about being a child, a journey about love and loss, a journey about courage, making sacrifices, saving turtles, loving all animals, a journey about witnessing violence and deception... and in the end it's a journey about growing up.  A definite must-play!  *Last update is just for Steam Awards.*

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a third-person linear co-op game and inspired by games such as Ico and Shadow of the Colossus due to their similarities in gameplay and aesthetics.   The premise of the game is following two brothers, Naie (eldest) and Naiee (youngest), through their journey across different lands searching for a magical tree which has the cure that can save their dying father. Being a very narratively driven game, revealing any details about the story would ruin much of the game’s charm since that is its main driving force.  The game plays exactly like a co-op puzzle-platformer where you control the two brothers through their journey. Throughout the game, using a controller is strongly recommended as playing it on keyboard, whilst still doable, can result in some awkward coordination between the two controllable protagonists when they start bumping into each other or objects like two drunks. The actual gameplay itself is satisfying due to the nice blend of “puzzles” requiring both brothers’ participation throughout most of the game. The difficulty of these “puzzles” may eventually feel disappointing after a while as they do not provide any concrete challenge to the player(s) (hence the inverted commas), although that might have been deliberate for the integrity of the game’s pace. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is, indeed, one of those games where the difficulty requires being at a minimum for the narrative to be at full throttle. Remember, no one wants to get constantly stuck solving complex puzzles in a narratively-driven game as it subsequently ruins the game’s pace.  However, where it lacks in challenging puzzles or even perhaps rewarding gameplay, it compensates for its narrative which in actual fact is the heart of this game. The journey, albeit disappointedly short, transports you in a world where you believe you are in a place like Middle-Earth; travelling through various mesmerising landscapes on your quest for the cure while the suiting soundtrack plays in the background. All of its narrative is achieved rather through visuals and gestures as there is not any comprehendible dialogue in the entire game. That in itself is commendable as not many games can pull it off as successfully as Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons does. Frankly, each gesture or visual representation is easily and surprisingly understandable. Besides all that, the game also offers in its storytelling a handful of moments of happiness, laughter, seriousness and sadness without feeling schizophrenic with its mood shifts. The game‘s narrative can have some amazing set-pieces, but also a couple of clumsy ones.  And that is as much as Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons can offer to players. On top of its colourful charm, or even some of its darker undertones, there are two main complains I personally had with this game in my first playthrough which ultimately felt detrimental to an extent towards my overall enjoyment. On a technical level, I encountered three game-breaking bugs which would not allow me to continue to the next area. Whilst two of them were solved by looking up online forums, the latter required restarting two prior chapters since simply restarting the current one was not sufficient to solve the problem. As of now, I still have no idea how those bugs triggered when it seems that the majority of people never even encountered them in the first place. Still, having to restart two complete chapters is bothersome. Then lastly, the ending. I will honestly be one of those in the minority who was not totally satisfied with the story’s conclusion nor did it have an impact on me. Even as I wish to critically evaluate it in this review, I cannot do that without simply spoiling it. But I will say this: I understood what they tried to achieve with the coming of age approach, but reflecting back through the entire journey, the writing at this point was sloppy and felt more of a cop out in the end to me. It also made me realise how Naie was not fleshed out as a character as much as his younger brother, Naiee, making a certain event not as effective as the developers would have hoped for, to me at least. Perhaps that is because the story might have been moving a bit too fast for things to fully develop.    Conclusively, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is one those video games where you delve in exclusively for the storytelling experience. Nothing more, nothing less. Without even sounding remotely pretentious, It is hardly the “masterpiece” everyone clams it to be, although it will definitely, and respectfully, leave a lasting impression for many people regardless, especially for youngsters. But not for everyone. Mechanically, it has a solid co-op experience with extremely easy puzzles to solve and backed up by artistically appealing sceneries, a fitting soundtrack and a simple, yet immersive, narrative despite a few clumsy set-pieces and a somewhat unsatisfying ending. At full price, however, I would definitely not recommend this due to its short length (2-3 hours at most) and limited replayability as there is not much reason to revisit it anytime soon now that you know how the story wraps up. Conversely, considering it always goes as low as £1 during virtually any Steam sales, there is absolutely no excuse not to try this, and that is why I am recommending it in the end. Despite some of its flaws, I truly had fun playing it and thought it managed to do what it was aiming for mostly pretty well, even if I will probably not reflect too much upon it in the near future.

Summary: Brothers is an engaging, fun, frustrating and immersive afternoon's fun - requiring a pad.  It's a tough thing to talk much about Brothers - A Tale Of Two Sons. The game is compact; so there's little you can draw reference to without spoiling anything, and to ruin this beautiful little tale would do the reader a great disservice. That in itself should serve as a recommendation, though it comes with several caveats.  Firstly, there is only one reason why you would logically ever play Brothers twice, and that's to get achievements. As sad a statement as that is in many games, here it's in the games' favour, as the achievements here take the form of vignettes which occur off Brother's beaten (and entirely linear) path. These brief scenes take a variety of tones and forms, and some are more enjoyable than others (of course). The merit of this approach is that the achievements enhance the game rather than detract from it, and for this Brothers should be applauded. Find all of these asides from the main tale though, and that's it - nothing more to see here.  So, the game itself. Brothers is an isometric overhead adventure, in which you guide the titular big and little brothers (who call one another Naia and Naiee in the game world's language, whatever those words may mean) around various obstacles on their journey to find a cure for their ailing father. As we have come to expect, the game and soundtrack are both beautiful, with a visually realised and aurally rounded world waiting to be explored. The manner of exploration is probably the most talked about and easily discussed mechanic of the game, which to summarily recap, involves simultaneous control of both brothers. On a standard gamepad set-up, the left stick controls the big brother, right stick the little brother, with left and right triggers serving as each character's action/interaction button, and left/right bumper rotating the camera. This control scheme may be both the game's key draw and most off-putting mechanic depend on how you personally handle the remapping of ingrained controller use - the operation is fairly fluid and has a gentle enough curve to allow you to get used to it, and I personally found the system engaging and enjoyable, but I can see the same aspects frustrating and annoying many gamers.   Nonetheless, overcome the fact that you WILL at times be constantly running one brother into a wall while the other calls out to his counterpart for no reason, simply because the little brother is positioned to the left of the big brother and your mind has once again mapped the left stick to the left character and vice-versa, and you have a wonderful ride ahead of you.  And you will need a controller. Yes, the game has keyboard controls. Be aware however that the game itself will warn you that it is designed, specifically, to be controlled with a pad. On a keyboard certain tasks requiring rotation of both thumbsticks simultaneously... do not map well. I can't honestly recommend the game to anyone without a controller.  As to the story, events and specifics of the world - they should all be experienced for oneself. So long as you have some sort of empathy within you, this is a great little journey which will draw you in fully for three to four hours. The puzzles aren't particularly challenging at any part, there's no choices or branching story lines - and you won't mind. It's refreshing how streamlined and conservative Brothers is with it's mechanics, puzzles and set-pieces, and it deserves to be played both for and because of these aspects. The tone, whist initially whimsical, darkens considerably, to the point where I'd advise against playing the game with younger children. To give it a cinematic comparison, it starts off in Jim Henson's Labyrinth, moves into The Never-Ending Story, and ends... not joyfully. However; I wouldn't change a thing about it.  It is also very worth saying that just because you'll see the entire game in one or two play-throughs, it is still extremely re-playable and enjoyable each time. I fired up the game to check out the keyboard controls while writing this review and I felt an urge to play again immediately, which would make a fourth run at the game.  This really is a beautiful, innovative and rollicking yarn which asks for very little from the player and gives a ton back. The only hold-ups are the aforementioned potential control frustrations, and for those to whom it's a factor, the price. Not wishing to seem ♥♥♥♥♥rdly, for your average player, £12 for a three-hour game isn't great. When you take into account what you get for that price of entry, I'd have to say that yes, it is worth it, but I can't say I paid that for it as I picked up a cheap key. At half price this game is an absolute steal and should be purchased without reservation, at full price, give the points raised here a little thought before committing.  8.5/10 He Ain't Heavy

Thumbs Suggested: 2    It's not often I've liked a game so much that I've actually been willing to press even  more  buttons to tell the world how awesome or potentially life-saving something is. Well, I don't know about the latter, but  Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons  is indeed  awe some. Every scene and every image may induce awe-inspiring, jaw-dropping gazes upon its on-lookers thanks to fantastic art direction by Starbreeze Studios. Who'da thunk the makers of The Darkness and The Chronicles of Riddick games could make something so bright and colorful? But then again, maybe we shouldn't assume too much about Starbreeze's new-found love of color just yet. Even in the span of the game's three-hour playtime, there are several instances of “dem feels” to be had.   Brothers  may also wreak havoc on your thumbs and cranial wiring thanks to its unique control scheme. Each brother is assigned their own analog stick and trigger allowing them to move and carry out context-based actions independently of one another, leading to some pretty hilarious moments. I can't count how many times I've let go of the wrong trigger while one of the brothers dangles precariously from a ledge or chain, only for him to meet an untimely demise. The worst is when you have the brother controlled by the left-side of the controller on the right and vice-verse. It's a bit like trying to do a math problem upside-down. I dunno know, though; I'm pretty bad at math.  All these eccentricities of game design culminate into what is one of the best ending sequences in a video game to date. This is one you just have to experience for yourself, so I'll leave it at that. This is the kind of story-telling that the medium has been striving for the past couple of years thanks to a booming indie scene. If Siskel and Ebert were here today, they would have said, “Thanks to a severe case of carpal tunnel, we can't help but give  Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons   Two Thumbs Up! ”

Quite an enjoyable game with a very moving story told in a unique way.  Firstly, you *need* a twin stick controller to play this - you *might* be able to kludge your way through with the keyboard, but you really don't want to. If you don't have one, go in to the City and buy an XBox 360 controller right now - I'll wait.... OK, you have one? Good.  Now, I love a game with a good story, but let's be honest - in most games the story and gameplay are somewhat disconnected from each other and could just as easily be presented as two separate pieces of art. Heck, there are some games that would have done better to throw away one (or two!) of those pieces altogether!  This game is different - the story and the gameplay are both perfectly intertwined. Sure, it still has cutscenes, but the story is largely conveyed while you control the brothers throughout their journey. This game has managed to figure out how to use the unique properties of a video game to tell it's story, rather than relying on techniques from movies or novels like every other game.  There is also, no speach - well, at least not English. The characters do use body language and speak some kind of made up language to effectively convey emotion and meaning, without distracting from the story or journey at hand. If you have ever played The Sims or The Singles it's similar to the spoken 'language' in those games.  The story is very moving - I don't really want to spoil anything, especially as the game is not all that long and I couldn't do anywhere near as good a job as the game itself does. The basic premise is that the two brothers have to go on a journey far beyond their village, past troll mines and Giant's cities to find a tree that produces a healing exiler to cure their sick father (or so I gather - no English, remember?). I won't say anything more - you need to play it.  The gameplay is also pretty unique - at it's heart it's really a puzzle platformer where you have to use the strengths and weaknesses of each brother to manipulate levers to move obstacles to allow both to progress on your journey. None of the puzzles are particularly difficult, but they are still satisfying and there is enough variety that the gameplay never outstays it's welcome.  What makes the gameplay unique is that you control both brothers *simultaneousely* with both of the sticks on the controller. This can lead to a bit of brain♥♥♥♥ at times - often coping with that that was more difficult than the puzzles themselves, but it doesn't take long to get used to and is never a serious problem (so long as you remember which button is which brother when you need to let go of a ledge). This is an intense experience, albeit a short one.   The journey leads you through a quite surrealistic fantasy world which fluctuates between being joyful and depressing, though it clearly drifts towards the latter over the course of the game. There's not that much of a plot actually and as there is neither any on-screen text, nor any spoken language other than the unintelligible fantasy language the characters are using every now and then, the main focus clearly is the emotional impact rather than the actual plot. This is working great, though.  This cannot unconditionally be said about the controls, however. Controlling two characters at once with an actually very basic setup (using one analogue stick and one trigger per character, plus two buttons for camera control) is an interesting concept and nicely supports the narrative in certain ways, but it's really easy to get confused, especially in sections demanding that both brothers are simultaneously moved more or less precisely. You can certainly get used to it, but it might take a while and the game might actually already be over at that point ;)   You can easily plow through the game in three hours or probably even less. There's some replay value because of several optional parts - in fact, all of the game's achievements are completely optional. Then again, not each achievement is unlocked by an additional puzzle of some sorts, but sometimes simply by interacting with the right object long enough. The puzzles in general might be a bit too easy and for the most part they rather test your patience than your logical thinking. Pretty much all of them make great sense in the context of the journey, though - there's no tacked-on riddle solving that feels out of place.  All in all this game does indeed deserve the praise it's been getting ever since its release, and it is very easy to ignore the lack of challenge and the basic nature of the plot as it still delivers some satisfying gameplay and an emotionally impactful and visually beautiful experience.  For comparable titles, see Journey (PS3), Papo y Yo, and maybe Limbo.

That is, it rarely tells you what buttons you need to press. In fact, you've only got the movement controls for each brother and a button to make each of them separately interact with stuff in the environment. There's dialogue but it's audible only in gibberish and only serves to convey character emotion and build on the personalities of the cast. Through the journey you come to know the characters by the quirky way you control them, i.e. you'll probably end up paying more attention to one brother, while the other larks off in some other direction (keeping track of two characters at once is deceptively difficult.) Within a span of three hours, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons manages to build a world more engulfing and tell a story more compelling than some of the most expensive 40-hour-gameplay titles created by big studios, and does so without the use of any real spoken language the players can understand. You won't know where you are going until you get there, but the journey to the brothers' destination is beautiful and fascinating to see unfold.   Although there is a notice saying that the game requires a controller to play, I did so with a regular keyboard. Just use WASD and spacebar for the elder brother Naia, and arrow and Ctrl keys for younger brother Naiee. Whatever you do use, controlling the two brothers simultaneously can be a bit disorienting, and I recommend keeping each brother on the side of the screen that corresponds with the side of the keyboard/controller where their buttons/joysticks are located. It is pretty fun to figure out the little puzzles along the way, as much of the game requires the boys' cooperation to move the story along.  Even though it is short, Brothers is worth every penny. If you can catch it on sale, as it is at the moment of this review being written, you really have no reason not to buy it. If you find yourself frustrated occasionally, give yourself a break and pick up the game again soon. You will want to play it through to the very end. (And grab a hanky when you get there.)

Increible and charming game.   The control scheme allows for a set of unique and very creative puzzles. Although they are fairly easy and straightforward, they are well thought and entertaining. The fact that they where designed with the brothers cooperation in mind makes them quite unique and you won't see anything like it in any other single player experience. Contrary to what the store page says, it appears that the game CAN be played without a controller.   The excellent and yet simple storytelling in this game is yet another proof that well-designed videogames can be a form of art. Through a made up language the characters interact with each other and is up to the player to decipher what's going on by paying attention to the characters' body expressions and gestures. The game is obviously designed so that the story and emotions are easy to understand without the need of explicit dialogues, allowing the players to immerse themselves in this beautiful story by their own interpretations.  The game makes good use of the Unreal Engine, creating a fantasy-like universe with consistent elements with the overarching story and interactions between the Brothers. But it doesn't stop at that, as the game manages to create different environments for each chapters that are one more breathtaking than the other. From the remnants of a giants' battlefield to a glacial landscape filled with singing whales, every path the Brothers traverse was meticulously designed to resemble the syle of a pop-up storybook. This manages to convey the huge scale of the world that surrounds the characters and the significance of the journey of the two Brothers. I can't find words to describe how much this concept is enhanced by playing the game in 3D. Making the game work with a 3DTV is fairly easy with some software like Tridef 3D (I guess Nvidia's 3DVision should work aswell). And I must say, it looks like the environment objects and the camera angles were designed specifically with 3D in mind (and I suppose it wasn't like that, seeing as the game does NOT natively support 3D). This was easily one of the best 3D gaming experiences I ever had, and I look at the 2D screenshots I took while playing and unfortunately they feel extremely underwhelming compared to the sense of scope I felt during those parts.  Overall, this game is a must-buy/must-play. Even if you can't find a way to experience it in 3D, the art design is strong enough to stand on its own and the beautiful story of the two Brothers may still be something to catch you by surprise and actually make you feel for the characters. The lenght of the game is approximately 3 hours. Maybe more if you decide to go for a second run in order to get the achievements you may have missed, but they weren't much an incentive to me.  One detail (Spoilers?): I still can't figure out if this game was designed for kids, or if it was made for grown ups. It begins as a colorful and charming game, but it quickly turns dark and gritty, full of scenarios I'm not sure how a kid would respond to. The easy puzzles also trew me off. But either way, the game is still something that should be experienced from beggining to end, even by adults.

TL-DR: An awesome game  The controls of the game were really hard for me to learn and I had some brain lags with it till the end - but that was fully worth it. Honestly, what can I say... I never cried so much in my life. This is not a game for very sensible persons (like me). I just finished the game and I need to hug my teddy bear really long to get over the story.  In terms of gameplay, I actually have nothing negative to report. The controls are simple but can still confuse as you go on in the adventure. The puzzles are quick to understand and can be solved without experiencing much frustration. Sometimes, I think it might be a little bit too easy. There is no part where you can get stuck or that is really challenging in my opinion. Still, I don't see it as a problem since the game is not about feeling awesome after solving a hard puzzle or bypassing a large obstacle and more about telling the story of the brothers. Difficult puzzles would maybe ruin this experience.  The narrative of the story is just fantastic. Even without using an acutal understandable language (the characters in this game speak some a made-up language + there are no subtitles), it is always clear what the characters in the game are saying or what they are talking about (also because they use gestures which helps out a lot). The story and (if existend) the relation of the individual characters is easily understandable.  Sure, the game is pretty short (it took me two hours to finish it without having all achievements) but I think it's the right length. Since the gameplay is simple, you can only do so much to keep it fresh and entertaining. Maybe one level more wouldn't have hurt but I don't think it's necessary either.  All in all, Borther - A Tale of Two Sons is an entertaining, small and also emotional experience. If you're looking for a quick and fun game and you're not the most sensible person out there (*sob*), definitly check out this game!

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons manages to accomplish something few games attempt to achieve; it tells an emotional and compelling story. The basic premise of the game is that of two brothers who have set out on a quest through a fantasy world to find a mystical cure for their ailing father.  To be reductive, the game is a simple puzzle-driven adventure game in which you control each brother with one of the analogue sticks and perform context sensitive actions using the triggers. It's through this control scheme that makes you fully see the Brother's reliance on each other and while the game is by no means hard, you'll find yourself focusing on the emotional context of the puzzles rather than the solution (which is almost always pretty straight forward).  The game has a sort of breezy (no pun intended) dream like quality to it. You'll travel through beautiful fairy tale-esque environments, non of which overstay their welcome, highlighted by gorgeous camera angles. There's an incredible sense of scale, distance and perspective and for a 'small' game it's amazingly impressive.  This is the type of game that really showcases just how unique and powerful a video game story can be when gameplay is utilised to help tell that story.

Brothers bills itself as an “epic fairy tale”, and while I’m generally hesitant to endorse that kind of hyperbole, two playthroughs left me with little doubt that it deserves that lofty description.   For one, Brothers unquestionably succeeds as a fairy tale, conjuring up a large dose of the whimsy, scope, and spectacle that one expects from the genre. In the space of a few hours, you’ll tiptoe past giants in cavernous mines, gaze upon the aurora borealis while crossing snow-capped peaks, beat back wolves in a menacing forest, swing through the ruins of an ancient castle, and hang glide through a forested valley. Brothers understands that fairy tales succeed in part because they appeal to the wild, unconstrained parts of our imagination, and it parlays this knowledge into a whirlwind journey that transports the player across a series of diverse Scandinavian landscapes. This Scandinavian character manifests itself in far more than just the game’s gorgeous setting, however. While Brothers is undoubtedly a fairy tale, it is a fairy tale in the image of Hans Christian Anderson and other masters of the genre, a story that eschews the simple platitudes of children’s narratives for a complex, emotional story that is not afraid to confront more mature themes of guilt, loss, and personal sacrifice. The game certainly has a number of light-hearted moments, and they are essential in the development of the story’s unique charm, but it also has distinctive moments of darkness, searing images that wrest us from our contentment and remind us of the risks and dangers inherent in such an epic undertaking.   On a more mechanical level, the control system, which allows you to manipulate both brothers simultaneously, can best be described as “stripped down”. Each brother’s actions are mapped to one side of the controller, with one button (the trigger) solely responsible for all potential actions. This streamlined control scheme saves you the trouble of having to simultaneously execute advanced button sequences, and substantially reduces the learning curve of what could otherwise have been an overly complex system. As it stands, the control scheme holds up well. It takes a little getting used to at first, and there are times when you might wish that you could toggle actions (some actions will require you to just hold down the trigger for extended periods of time), but within half an hour or so you’ll be zipping through the game’s gorgeous environments with relative ease. It isn’t wildly innovative, but it pushes the traditional boundaries of single-player gaming enough to make the game’s numerous puzzles seems fresh and exciting, even if they tend not to be overly difficult to solve.   While I loved the story and appreciated the simple elegance of the controls, I think my favorite part about Brothers is the frequent, subtle nods the game makes to the playfulness and insatiable curiosity of childhood. Our titular heroes may be on an epic journey of life and death importance, but they still have the realistic mannerisms of kids who are just soaking up the wonders around them. They laugh in amazement when a friendly giant helps them ascend a steep cliff. They playfully interact with strangers on their initial journey through their village. They gaze in awe at the stars, pointing upwards at the luminous constellations which light their journey. These small but frequent touches humanize our protagonists and connect them to the player. We might not be able to empathize with the precise struggles and concerns that the brothers face on their epic journey, but we can all relate to the sense of wonder we feel when we witness something heretofore unimagined, a sense that lies at the heart of what makes fairy tales, and this game, special.   It certainly isn’t the only thing that makes this game stand out. The music is as effectively stripped down as the control scheme, a subtle tour de force of haunting chanting and mournful viola and piano melody lines which mirrors the grim nature of the brothers’ task. The environments are lush, beautifully animated, and incredibly diverse. The graphics themselves aren’t particularly cutting edge (rather reminiscent of Fable, actually), but the level design is nothing short of breathtaking, with the traversable parts of it every bit as gorgeous as the wonders visible just off the beaten path. But in the end, I think this game succeeds most as a plaintive ode to the curiosity and wonderment of childhood, and as a reminder that there are moments of joy and laughter to be found even amongst the most dire of circumstances. You’ll be hard-pressed to find a better way to spend an evening.

'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' is absolutely amazing in terms of the  beautiful, breathtaking scenery design . And, controlling two people at the same time is certainly novel. No, you can't play this game by moving one person and then the other. You must be able to move them both simultaneously (or nearly so) to be able to get through some areas. It can be played without a game controller. I played the entire game using  only a keyboard  (after remapping the keys), because my controller just died. I am sure that added to the time it took also.  I am glad I played the game, so I recommend it. However, it is with some reservations. (1) I would not recommend this to a very young person or to anyone that might be easily affected by negative imagery. Besides being heavy on emotional situations (sadness, despair, ...), there are areas I can only describe as gruesome. And, the overall story is bittersweet. (2) Don't buy it if you want hours and hours of game play. To really enjoy the game you must think like you are on travel and want to see all the sites, scenery, and animals. That's important because the game is very easy to get through quickly. I did it in 10 hours, taking my time and getting all the achievements, and even replaying some really cool parts    (maneuvering the inventor's glider)  .  (3) Would I play this through repeatedly like I did with Portal or Knights of the Old Republic? No, I probably won't. It doesn't have that kind of replay value. The story is very linear.  All that being said, I did enjoy the game and its artfulness.

This is the first game that I bought and played on steam.  Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a marvel of storytelling and clever gameplay and a must buy for players who enjoy such.  The first thing that I should say is that unlike what the notice says on the store page, this game does not require a controller to play.   Gameplay and story: During the game you control these two characters with the arrow and wasd keys as the camera adjusts itself to the area that you are playing. The game itself is relatively simple and linear, requiring the player to overcome easy obstacles in the way of the protagonists' journey to save their ill uncle. In the course of their quest, they assist others in need and grow closer as brothers. It is slightly challenging to get ahold of controlling the brothers simultaneously at the start of the game but becomes much more fluid and easy as you progress through the levels even with a keyboard. Complement to the controls, the challenges along the way begin to require more ingenuity as you learn to control the brothers.  Graphics: The areas themselves are beautifully designed and the game pauses every once in a while to allow you to enjoy it. From climbing crumbling ruins to scaling massive caves the game uses every area to show you just how beautiful and well crafted it is.   Sound: There is no major dialogue so to speak but everything in the game is clear without it using too many words. What the lack of dialogue gives way to is a wonderful soundtrack that captures the emotional range of the story in ways that dialogue would never have. As the game becomes darker the longer you play, the sounds and music mature likewise.  Overall:  On the front, Brothers may look like a simple, light hearted puzzle adventure for a casual player. Playing it, I've come to appreciate the subtle and fine ways that this game was made elevating it in quality above many of the other games that I play. The story and gameplay are simple, the music complements the graphics excellently, and the entire experience is an emotional journey as two brothers enter dark and dangerous worlds to save their family.   I cannot recommend this game enough and constantly badger anyone who would listen. It is a quick (approx 6 hr) playthrough and the ending left me sobbing. I have to say, this is a different caliber of gaming. I've never experienced anything like it  10/10

I better start off with this: I was recommended to play this by TotalBiscuit, as I had seen his 'WTF is' before I played the game. He said that this game might be the best game ever made in his opinion, and I started the game with that in mind. Now, as to whether or not this is the best game ever made, I will let that be up to you, but I can say that I don't think it's the best game ever made. It was a really nice movie.  Yea thats pretty much my opinion There isn't a whole lot of actual gameplay in the game, it is mostly running from point A to B, get up this cliff, get over this bridge. And the gameplay that was there, could be a bit confusing, because you had to control two characters at once. It was pretty easy to get past, and the times I got confused wasn't really enough to pull me out off the game. I think this game could be defined as a story driven puzzle game, although the puzzles wasn't all that hard, and more often than not, they were very simple. I didn't really encounter a puzzle that really had me think, and all of them was pretty much obvious. The gameplay of this title is in my opinion the weakest part of this game, and it is pretty weak. If the story and world hadn't been there I would say it was a pretty bad game. Speaking of the world. I got sort of a Zeno Clash vibe from the world, because it had the same way of having wierd animals, trolls, and oversized buildings lying around. It had sort of the same psychedelic dream setting, although not anyway near as weird as Zeno Clash. I really liked the setting, and the game uses a system with some benches that function as vistas as you sit on them, to show off the world. The world definitely had a lot of wackiness to it, and the chapters where sort of themed, as you pass through the different areas. The graphics wasn't anything good, and it was obvious to see that the game is optimised for xbox (although I have heard it shouldn't run all that well on xbox). Textures weren't all that high quality, but that didn't really matter as the art style is a cartoonish style. Although it came for xbox first, the pc port, if it even is a port, is pretty good. I had a steady 60 fps all the way through, and not a single lag spike. As for the controls I personally played with a controller, which seems to work the best as well but I tried the keyboard controls and they seem to play just fine, so really don't HAVE to play with an xbox controller but it is recommended. I saved the best for last: the story. The story is definitely the strongest part of the game. The story is really good, and Starbreeze somehow managed to convey the whole thing without a single real word. All spoken language in the game is pretty much gibberish (it might be a real language, but you aren't expected to understand anything from it). Even though everything said is gibberish, it is really easy to understand the messages conveyed between the characters of the game. And there is absolutely no problems in understanding the story. The story is very emotional, but it didn't make me cry, as it did TB (guess people really are different after all ;)). Although single manly tear at the ending. So is this worth buying. In a way, you can think of as this: it is pretty much the price you would pay to go see a new movie in the theaters so if you are looking for a great story, in a game Wahtzy could beat in 2 hours 33 minutes, this would be worth it. If you are looking for an actual game, I would say this isn't worth the full price, and if you aren't interested in story at all I would say you should pretty much just avoid it. As for replayability, I only managed to get a single achievement, so I guess there is a reason to play through it a second time. TL;DR:  If you are looking for a movie length game with a great story then BUY IT. If you are looking for a game to play, secondarily with a good story, then: Buy it when its on sale.  If you are looking a game, but aren't interested in story at all: AVOID.  Edit: I corrected a lot of spelling errors. Turns out I can't spell opinion.

Short but sweet.   This is a wonderfully imaginative adventure with one or two truly memorable moments - moments that will live with you long after this game has sat gathering dust on your (virtual) shelf, kind of like  that moment  in Bioshock, or  that moment  in Final Fantasy VII. If you've played those games, you'll know what I'm talking about, and once you've played Brothers, you'll know exactly which moments I'm referring to.  It's a very pretty game with some great scenery aided by the fantasy setting. The closest comparison would be Fable. The palettes never get boring because your journey takes you through some incredible and progressively dark and dangerous landscapes, so you really feel like you've wandered far, far away from the comfort of your peaceful village where your biggest concern was the local bully.  Audio is also decent. There is speech of a sort - the inhabitants of the world speak a sort of gibberish language similar to what you'd hear characters in The Sims speaking. The soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful. In a longer game it would become repetitive but as Brothers is a short game, it never feels samey.  Speaking of length, I personally feel that the length of the game was just about right, but I'm aware not everyone may agree with this. Clocking it at about 3 hours, it's a short game for the price. However, I picked it up for half price during a Steam sale and would say it's well worth the money. It's well-paced and I'm glad the developers didn't try to pad it out any longer or drag it out unnecessarily.  Moving on to the gameplay - the control system is unique and innovative (perhaps it's been done before, but I've not played a game like it) - it's effectively one-player co-op. Playing with a controller, you control one brother with the left stick and make him interact with the environment using the left trigger, while you control the other brother in exactly the same way using the right stick and the right trigger. This did lead to me getting my knickers in a twist and trying to walk both brothers off opposite ends of a cliff repeatedly (don't worry, they won't) and takes some getting used to, but it's a great system. The puzzles are extremely simple and will barely slow you down. In fact, the trickiest puzzles (and that's a relative term) come from obtaining the optional achievements, none of which are required to complete the main story.  In conclusion, if you don't mind paying for a pretty, casual (read: easy) 3 hour adventure with little to no replay value (other than wanting to re-live  those moments ), then I couldn't recommend Brothers highly enough.

'Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons' is my Game of the Year for 2013. 2013 is the year I started to move away from 'AAA' games and start looking at indie games. I've played a few great ones, but 'Brothers' transcends the gaming medium into an experience you would expect from a television series or a feature film.  The most obvious thing about 'Brothers' is the control scheme. You have not played a game like this before. One controller (and you do need a controller, though a keyboard can be used, despite what the store page says) controls both brothers. Stick moves, trigger is a context-based 'use' button. Left for older, right for younger. It makes sense, and it works 99% of the time. The only trouble is when they cross over (you'll want to keep the older brother left of the younger brother) but that's easy to fix, stop them both and start with one, then add the other. You might notice my Steam avatar is from Rockband; the same technique is useful there as well when playing guitar or drums. Start with one beat, then add the others one at a time.  Most of the puzzles are fairly basic. When you realize that a ladder out of reach means the older brother has to hoist the younger brother up, you'll use that a few more times. However, the game doesn't feel redundant. It does challenge you in new and different ways, but the mechanics are all generally the same. Pretty much, once you get the hang of it, the puzzles seem to come second nature, which is necessary for this game to work the way it does. You aren't meant to get hung up on puzzles; rather, you may fail a couple times, but once you have that 'A-ha!' moment and realize what you need to do—it just clicks.  The story is all kinds of wonderful and amazing. There are things about it I just can't talk about. It's like a film, you don't want to give away what happens in the second half, or the last two-thirds. Most of these scenes, I'm sure, will come out in the next few months, as more and more people play it. The ending will be given away. It was actually spoiled for me, or at least a part of it. I still found it incredibly moving. There's this thing that happens, and I just couldn't believe the game made me do that. And then afterwards. It's been about 6 hours and my mind is still being blown when I think about it.  $15 for a 3.5 hour game (that's about what it took me) seems high, but it's worth every cent. It will probably go on sale, but this is one you will want to play before all your friends. Because hearing about those incredibly moving parts, wouldn't be the same as actually experiencing them. Don't cheat yourself.

Having never written a review before, it seems only fitting that my first be a review of Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, for I can, with no reservations, say that this is my favorite game. Let it first be understood that I have an affinity for casual games with unique elements. That being said, Brothers has everything that I look for in a game: an interesting plot, a unique game mechanic, and a beautiful universe, among many other things. The first thing you notice about the game is the truly unique control system. The player controls two people simultaneously using the two analog sticks and just two buttons. This takes some getting used to but the game eases you into it before throwing tough puzzles that require some rather ambidextrous fingerwork at you, all the while providing you with a great soundtrack and one of the most beautiful and interesting surroundings. The world these two prothers live in is never said aloud but it was most likely inspired by the game writer's Nordic home. Although the brothers start in a small coastal village, they soon journey throughout their world, passing through neighboring towns, trolls' fortresses carved into mountains, cities inhabited by only frozen citizens and invisible giants, and even an epic battle fought between men taller than mountains. In each new place the boys enter, they try to save someone in need, or avoid getting sacrified, eaten, or frozen. It is worth noting that throughout the entire game, not a single word is spoken in any understandable language. Despite this, the game manages to elicit intense emotions as the brothers struggle with the world around them, those they meet, and each other on their quest to save their father. I have no shame in admitting that I may have shed a tear at the end. Overall, this game is one of the best I've ever played and would recommend wholeheartedly to anyone looking for an adventure of a lifetime.

I've never reviewed a game on Steam, but if you haven't played Brothers yet - you should.  Gameplay wise, it's a puzzle game. A very balanced one at that - the levels are not too easy to figure out, but not so difficult that make you resort to walkthroughs. It is tricky, but very interesting, to control two characters at once - and it does feel like you're playing co-op with yourself. While it's just a matter of moving the sticks and pressing the triggers, it doesn't feel repetitive because of the variety of actions that the brothers perform when pressing the trigger - plus, the little extra activities (that give you achievements) are a nice touch that break from the normal mechanics of the game.  Story wise, I have been blown away. The characters are brilliantly defined for a game that has no in-game lines. The way the two brothers interact differently with the same environmental items or NPCs work perfectly to give insights on their personalities in an indirect way. The main plot is quite standard, but I personally did not anticipate the ending, nor of course the various 'challenges' the brothers face on the way to their goal.   The game is also stunning graphically and musically - the theme is heartwrenching and the environments (beautifully designed) are illuminated gloriously, and they can be observed via the use of well-thought panoramic benches through the game. Tl;dr - this game is a joy to the eyes (and the ears).  Overall, play this game and you will not regret it. The only downside is that it's short (please don't look at my gameplay time on here - I played offline so that's not accurate, but I'd say it's probably around 4 hours) and because of the fact that puzzles can only be solved one way, I don't think there's much of a replayability factor.   Still, it's now up there with my favourite games, so please do yourself a favour and play this!

A really memorable and well-crafted experience. It's one of the few experiences that actually reminded me of how I remember my childhood: it started with a strong fairy tale feel where something is not quite right, and gradually grew progressively grim as the brothers were thrust into a world where children are not immune to hardship. Before playing it, I was concerned it would be another recycled story about annoying/sad/bratty stock-character kids, but I'm pleased to say that it's one of the more balanced and mature portrayals of children that shows them as human beings with an actual personality.  In terms of gameplay, the way they combined it with the story development makes Brothers one of gaming's gems: all the story is told through the environment and the interactions the player has with the world, and there is no (comprehensible) dialogue.   The best story moments are twists based on how you control both brothers in different situations. One of my favorite examples is an area where you need to avoid detection from a monster by hiding in specific positions behind frozen statues. Another is a battlefield for giants, where navigating the environment becomes a nice twist. All the areas you explore are filled with little contextual interactions that will make you will feel like you 'toy'with this unforgiving world and its inhabitants, just like a child would.   Complementing this approach is a truly special and stylized art direction, the kind that makes me stop and take screenshots every minute or so.The amount of soul & care put in the details of this game, from memorable story moments to little interactions in the world, is rare to find in games nowadays. Very short but very sweet.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is simply put, one of the best game I have ever played. Never have I been so captivated by characters whos words are mere emotional cues.   You are dropped into a world which has a delightful charm on its own and control two main protagonists in which you solve puzzels and explore the fantasy world that Starbreeze has created. You are taken on an adventure with epic proportions with some helpful (and evil) characters who can help guide you and create a great tone for the game. One thing that I really found interesting about the game is that even though its charm gives off a somewhat happy tone for the game, however Starbreeze has shown in this game that no matter how the game looks you can also give off a very grim mood as well and I am glad that they chose to create a somewhat mature story that people can understand and possibly relate to the characters. The Starbreeze developers we're able to create a world with great visuals and also had a very simple goal in mind but allowed you to choose for yourself what really happened story wise by not giving the characters much oral interaction. Even though there isn't oral interaction between the characters (that we can understand), you can easily tell what emotions the characters are feeling and I think it was a fantastic feature.   I hope you enjoy this game as much a I did. I also hope that you forgive me that I left out a lot of information about the story because I would like you to experience it on your own and my input would most likely affect how you feel about the outcome.   ~Ratings~ -Visuals 10/10- -Sound 9/10- Could have seen maybe more ambient sounds at some points -Gameplay 9/10- Great puzzles however some trouble sometimes haveing the characters activate some keyparts in the puzzle or characters getting stuck (VERY RARELY) -Replayability 7/10- I would say if you beat this once you will most likely not play it again. Its very linear with some optional parts but nothing enough to make you come back unless you want to hear the story again. -Story 10/10- Game of the year material

Rather, achievements are awarded for going off the beat and track and sometimes doing unconventional things. TL;DR, play it!   The Good    Innovative : The core mechanic of controlling two characters simultaneously with a single gamepad is something I've never seen before, and it works great! More than that, Brothers is an adventure that takes place across unique and unexpected set pieces. I was constantly surprised and delighted at what I found every time I turned a corner.    Controls : Though I would often lose track of which thumb controlled which character, as a whole, the gameplay is incredibly intutive.    Story : Brothers masterfully tells a beautiful narrative. It's short and sweet, it's thrilling, and it's got a lot of heart!    Art : It's pretty and I like colors.   The Bad   There was this one musical motif they kept playing where the vocalist was all, 'Eeeeeeee heeeeeee,' and it was annoying.   I wish the game had a keyboard mapping so more people could play it, because you should totally play it!

What the game lacks in length, it makes up for in depth. Brothers is a unique experience that is reminiscent of the games put out by Team ICO. You're dropped into a world with only the most basic of instructions: travel to a far away place to get a cure. The controls took a little getting used to since you're constantly controlling two characters at the same time, but after about the first chapter or so, I was surprised at how natural the dual joysticks worked for this game. The scenery is gorgeous and the puzzles are fun (if not a little on the simple side). My favorite chapter is the one where you're traversing the corpses of fallen giants. No explanation is given or needed as to why there are newly fallen giants all over the place; in fact, each level has its own charm of unexplained circumstances. Nevertheless, the level design is superb and the mysteries of the chapters do not detract whatsoever from the experience. My only complaint is that the game is relatively short.

Game Name: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons Original Release: 2013 Personal Rating: A Estimated Playtime: 3 hours Multiplayer/Coop?: None Played on: Steam Controller  Brothers- A Tale of Two Sons is a great game. I received my Steam Controller a while ago and decided that I needed to get into the groove of using a controller. I've always used a keyboard and mouse combo, and this seemed like a great game to use the controller with, and I couldn't cheat and use KB/M since it is controller only.   Controls: The controls are very simple to use. A joystick to move and the trigger allow the brother to use their special move. The twist? You have to control both brothers at the same time. On the steam controller this meant using the joystick and the right touchpad. Was it useable? Definitely. Not to mention that it was easy enough for a controller noob like me to get used to.  Graphics: The graphics are very indie-ish. This isn't a demanding game at all, but what makes it special is how the graphics interact with the artwork and the background to create the story. The creators place benches around the game and through the brother's special moves, you are able to sit down and observe the scenery.   Music: The music fits the mood perfectly. From the funny and entertaining interactions that the brothers have with the other characters, to the scary and odd moments that leave you satisfied with the way that the scenes end.  Overall: Highly recommended. It is basically an interactive movie. The cut scenes meld together with storyline, audio, art and graphics that allow you to forget that you are playing a game. You will love entering the world of brothers trying to save their single father, all the while speaking an unknown language, and will have you crying by the end.

You feel the weight of the characters hanging on the ledges because you control their ability to stay up there by using your own grip (LT/RT). If they fall, it is because you dropped them. You get to interact with so many different parts of the game. There are even different interactions put in for the different brothers. If you interact with a person/object with one, the other may do something silly instead. While those choices do not often affect the game, they can be pretty entertaining. I would reccomend this game to anyone and everyone.

This little game was a positive surprise for me. I heard a lot of good things about it before but I figured it's just another edgy indie game. Turns out it's a fantastic adventure game with some pretty original ideas. Basically you play as two brothers. Playing with a controller, you control the older brother with the left stick and left trigger and the younger brother with the right stick and right trigger. The older brother is stronger and taller than the younger one who can get through tight places. Then you start making your way to this huge magical tree to get its healing juices for your dying father. During your way there you encounter lots of different people and creatures, some of which are bumholes and some of which you'll want to help. There's some puzzles and lots of platforming, each of which needs the brothers to bro-operate in order to get past the various obstacles.  The world feels huge, and not just because there's giants everywhere. You go from a tiny sort of swedish village to troll dungeons to winter wonderlands and graveyards. All of the dialogue is in gibberish and yet the game manages to convey the story and the feelings of the two brothers perfectly to the player. Without spoiling anything, there are things in the world that make you wonder what happened there, or things that are currently happening that make you want to know the backstory of it all. It gives more meaning to the world around you, while leaving the details to your own imagination. All of this combined with the great soundtrack creates a really magical atmosphere where it feels like some sort of a very depressing but beautiful fairytale fantasy world.   All in all the game is very enjoyable and emotional. The idea of controlling two characters at the same time in this way is something I personally haven't seen any other game do before, and it works. It is a short game, but it's definitely worth the price tag.

Note that the keyboard is only able to register 2 keys pressed at once, not 4.  2. Incredible Story I love how touching the story is at the beginning, although I do begin to doubt the wisdom of the physician. Sending 2 young kids to search for a magic water while putting their lives at risk does sound a bit irresponsible.  3. Imaginative and Immersive World Trolls, Giants, Giant Orcas, Ice Sea Turtles, Invisible Ice Monsters, Spider Woman, Blood of Giant Tribes, Hippogryphs, Hang Gliders, Monster Roots/Trees, these are just some of my favourite things.  4. Interactions It's amazing how you can interact with so many things e.g. Spitting into a well, each additional well you spit into adds another spit droplet. Picking up balls and playing basketball.
