Recommended, but not the masterpiece it's hyped up to be.  I don't remember how I came to own this game. Probably a Humble Bundle, but not sure. What I do know is that I didn't pay the asking price of $15, and it's not worth it at that price.   So, what is it? It's a game about two brothers trying to find a miracle cure for their father, who appears to be terminally ill. I say appears to be because nothing in the game is actually explained. You're expected to come up with the how's and why's of everything you encounter, similar to a 'create your own adventure' type game, only your adventure is down a straight and narrow path.   The controls are simple. I used a 360 controller and everything comes down to four buttons. Left stick controls older brother, right stick controls younger brother, left trigger makes older brother grab things, right trigger makes younger brother grab things. Simple as you like.   Let's get into the actual game, shall we. For roughly two hours, you'll guide the two brothers to their destination, doing very basic platforming, repeatedly. There really is no challenge to it, no thought required. As you do the very basic platforming, you come across some rather interesting landscapes. Herein lies one of the two main issues I have with the game. You'll come accross some interesting stuff in your journey. However, nothing, and I do mean absolutely nothing, is explained. As I mentioned earlier, you're left to come up with your own reasons for what you're seeing. Some people may enjoy that. I really didn't. Thought and care obviously went into the game world, so why not give an explanation as to what is going on? SPOILERS AHEAD:  For instance, one part of your journey takes you through an area littered with the bodies of freshly dead giants. The actual gameplay through this area is quite brilliant, but I kept thinking to myself, 'what happened here?' The answer never appeared. Soon, I was traversing through a new part of the land, the giants completely forgotten.  The other problem I have with it is how MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD:    The older brother dies. Let's recap his death shall we? They rescue a girl from some religious fanatics. The older brother shows her the map of where they need to go, and she leads the way. Eventually, she guides the brothers into a cave, where she inexplicably turns into a spider and attempts to kill them. What transpires is a very easy boss fight in which the the brothers work together and rip off her legs. Of course, while ripping off her last leg, the older brother gets stabbed in the chest. When this happened I just said to myself. 'alright, you ripped of the other five legs with no problem , now you get shanked? Lol.' Also, why would a spider posing as a girl get caught by religious fanatics? This happened a good distance away from her cave, BTW. As in, she had no reason to be there.  Also a small gripe I had is the ending. The ending is very somber, yet the music has this fantasy action hero type vibe. It's really strange and didn't fit at all, at least to me.   All in all, this game was decent. Had the potential to be great, but forcing the player to come up with reasons for everything happening in the game really took away from it. The platforming was also so basic that it didn't feel like much of a game. It felt like reading a pop-up story more than playing a video game. There is no replayability here. The $15 asking price is way too steep. Thankfully, the game seems to be on sale a lot. If you don't own it and want to play it, $5 or less is what you should pay.

Damn, I've just finished the game and I feel like sh*t. I was holding back manly tears all through the last 15 minutes of the game, and the ending just devastated me. I was just a seconds away from breaking down like a little girl. What an emotinal journey.  Ahem. OK, here's the review. The game follows the story of two brothers who go on an adventure to save their father, who has a serious disease and the cure is literally on the other side of the world. They overcome lots of different problems (mostly platforming) on their journey and they even escape some life-threatening situations.  The developers managed to create an incredible world filled with hundreds of little bits of lore, something even some AAA titles, with huge budgets and an army of lore-masters, cannot manage. The atmosphere just pulls you in and never lets you go until the end. I really regret that I had to play this game in multiple sessions instead of in just one sitting. I suppose the atmosphere, the satisfaction I felt after I finished the game would be much more profound that way.  The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal. The game has one of the most goosebump-inducing soundtracks I've ever listened to. It suits the mood, the story so well that you'd think they made the game for the song, not the other way around.  The game is made with Unity engine (I think) and the graphics are very nice. I mean, it's not like they are cutting edge but the style they used for the game is incredibly atmospheric. A photorealistic game engine would really ruin the mood instead of enhancing it.  I played the game with an Xbox controller, and I have to admit, even with the controller the game was sometimes really difficult, some puzzles difficult to coordinate. Still, I had no real trouble. I really, really suggest a controller though; the game would probably be impossible to play with a keyboard.  All in all, I haven't felt this emotional thanks to a game since To the Moon. If you're looking for a game with an emotional story, perfect soundtrack and a cathartic ending, this is it.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is an adventure game where a single player controls two brothers as they search for a cure for their fathers illness. While in many games the function of controls is to be simple and allow the player to function as easily as possible, Brothers uses controls for more. The older brother is moved with the left stick and performs actions with the left trigger while the younger brother uses the right side of the controller. Initially this feels weird and you may get your movements criss crossed. But over the course of the adventure (which runs between 3 and 4 hours) you will get a feel for each brothers movements and characteristics. Not only does technical control increase over time but also a very strange physiological-emotional connection forms. This results in what I felt was higher emotional payoff during key parts of the game, especially the ending.  The game has an absolutely beautiful presentation. The characters are all charming and the multitude of environments are all very screenshot worthy. The world of the game is well constructed and feels very active in the places you only see at a distance. I got the feeling that I was in the middle of some northern european folk tale. The soundtrack is often sparse, using natural sounds from the environment, but when music is used it is done so for maximum emotional effect. There is little to no dialog in the game, just the brothers calling each other's names or expressive noises. This is fine though because the characters use very expressive body language to get information across.  This is probably one of the more unique games I've played in a while and I'm really scrounging to find something I didn't like. Its not very long, but a lot happens and its an enjoyable experience. I would highly recommend this game.  As a side note apparently this game CAN be played with keyboard and mouse. I tried it and would discourage this. This game was made with a controller in mind and the controls are an important part of the experience.

The game lacked a lot of impact for me and the story wasn't anything to write home about. However it was still a nice experience and the art style and graphics are quite nice.  (I played this game entirely on the xbox 360 gamepad by the way.)  This game felt like a dark childrens book, it was quite whimsical at times, very funny and silly, but it got hauntingly dark too. And thankfully, without remorse. That, is a very strong mark for this game. I think this may be a spoiler, but I was really expecting it to undo what it had done. I am very glad that it didn't.  Before I get to where I want to go, I want to talk about the controls. The controls tangled your fingers up into a knot, I don't really mind that. But with the very simple control layout, this game controlled very basically. The controls were not interesting in the slightest and really it just boiled down to building a control scheme onto that same controller in essence. Wasn't really anything ground breaking. You could change your camera view, move two characters with the analouge sticks. And then you have two action triggers/keys, for each of the respective characters. So really you'd just move around and press the action trigger/key and see what happens.  By the way, this game's store page lied, you DON'T need a xbox 360 controller to play this game. You can play it on the keyboard too as I could tell in the options menu.   Anyway, I don't really know how to explain why it felt like and experience to me over a story. Perhaps it has to do with how shallow everything felt regarding characters. I felt like absolutely no one had a real backstory or depth besides the young boy. Using them to interact with the world had very expressive reactions. The older brother was boring, he was completely neutral the entire story and just struck me as a faceless robot kind of chugging along on this quest. Even his 1 flashback was really shallow and boring and felt irrelevant. It just reminded me of the father i'm trying to save. It didn't give the brother any face-value and only seemed to show aggression to his brother at time when his brother was unokay with something. That or he'd just show leadership or be protective of his brother. Other than that, he had absolutely no depth whatsoever and he was easily forgettable. Really, I felt only interested in him cause he looked cool. I didn't like the little brother because he looks like a doof to me. But after watching the little bothers events and personality and backstory unfold a little bit (not enough I'd say) he was much more interesting and likeable.  Next up is the graphics. Graphics were good, I mean. I am unsure about the detailing, at times they felt not shaded enough, detailed enough, or they didn't flow together well enough. Though the graphics and displays and scenery was good enough to definitely warrant a second playthrough with your finger on the steam screencapture key, that's for sure. Definitely good desktop wallpaper material in here. Also can be aspring for some artists I can imagine.   There were some moments of tenseness in this game, surprisingly. As the game got progressively dark and took a really unexpected dip into limbo-like depressive stuff all of a sudden. I think there was only one or two parts that really made me have to actually pay attention to my controls, very sure it was once only. And that was a damn good part, glad it wasn't necessary to the story, felt very important to me though. And I like that, i'm glad I got a opportunity to side-track in the game and find things that were important to me instead of the characters. It was nice.  That being said, this games trip into darkness and doing scenarios that aren't often done in video games was truly surprising and i'm really glad they didn't regret any of the decisions they decided to do in it. Because I feel like that's what saved the game for me a little bit. It was a nice journey and it was fun and relaxing. Most deaths in this game really only occur when the controls are a little too unclear, but you figure out what went wrong almost immediately, so it's not big deal.  That being said, I'd really like to give the developers a BIG thumbs up to one part they made me do. It was something I never want to do in a video game ever again, it just felt all kinds of wrong and messed up to me. I'd like to compliment another part about it, but. I won't, cause spoilers. But, it was good. And i'm glad you didn't reverse it.   Also, lastly. The music. ...It was really easy to ignore it. It really was. It wasn't bad by any means, but it wasn't anything to remember. When my mind actually did pick up some of the tracks, I was instantly dissuaded to bother youtube searching it because that same track felt like a reoccuring theme in any 'deep' moments. Whenever something interested happened or a cutscene happened, tracks that sound like that song I heard. Sounded just like remixed versions of it with added or removed instruments and spacing between instrument play times and so on so forth to fit the timing they wanted to match or feelings they wanted to convey in the cut scenes. So the only interesting track was pretty much just rehashed to me in a uninteresting way and most of the scenes were impactful. Even the ones that were supposed to bother you. Also with that, I don't get why they put this skyrim-sounding song at the end of the game. It really made no sense, it was all epic and then nothing happened. After everything that happened in the game, it made absolutely no sense when it played. It didn't match the mood of what was going on at all. I don't know who's choice that was, but it wasn't a good one.  Anyway, while the game was lackluster in personality I feel, as far as experience goes it was quite something and it was definitely a pleasurable way to spend my morning and part of my afternoon. I would recommend this to someone who wouldn't mind going on a enjoyable light puzzle/adventure. If you want to get your hands on this game, sure, I suppose 14.99 is a fair asking price. However I think paying ten bucks for this product is a good buy, any less than that is too low for what you're getting.   Anyways, thanks for reading my review. I hope it helped you in your decision to get this game or not. Have a good one.

I'lll be honest: I can hardly recommend this game.  It does not mean that it's a bad game, far from that.  Let's start with the  cons :  Life-time : the game took me less than 3 hours to complete, and the only motives to replay is to obtain the achievements. So yes, the game is incredibily short.  Gameplay : it's very original because you can control the two brothers at the same time, and it's also very simple, you just use 4 buttons (two analogics and RT and LT). Puzzles : They rarely challlenge you, pretty basic from the beginning to the end of the game. The only challenge here are the somewhat frustrating controls.  Now, the  pros !  Story : A beautiful and simple story, but also very cold, dark and sad. Graphics : Colorful, detailed, fairytale-like, sometimes it even makes you stop in the game just to watch the background, the nature, etc. The scenarios are also very varied! Long rant here:  There's a lot of things it does very right and few thing it does very, VERY wrong.  B:ATOTS does a good job at world building. It has its own made up language that characters spout as you walk through the ruins of places meant for people bigger than you. It's actually a lot like Shadow/Colossus in that sense, made less lonely by the fact that there's 2 of you. The town you start off in has a great deal of character in itself and even though it's linear, there's still a sense that it's a real place that you just happen to know your way around. This is helped by the camera, which some people have complained about because the game can't decide if you should be able to move the camera on your own or be subject to cinematic angles, but I'm one of those people who drives around in GTA in cinematic mode so I got used to it pretty quickly. It gives a sense of guidance in some of the more open sections of the game.   The core gameplay is basic 3D adventure/platforming made unique by the fact that you control 2 characters at once, the big brother with the left stick/trigger, and the little brother with the right. The game is probably too short for most people to fully get the hang of these controls, so aside from the core mechanic, the game is very easy. Easy might be a negative for some of you. I don't know.   If you aren't really worried about your dying father, you can interact with almost anything in the game. You can sit down on a bench and enjoy the view, which the game never falters on making sure is nothing short of eye candy. On top of that, you can butt in on other people and examine objects, and there's a good amount of character development for each brother because they interact with everything differently.   The differences between the 2 brothers is also expertly displayed in the gameplay. There are a handful of people/things you have to interact with in order to progress. The little bro comes across as carefree/immature with everything he interacts with, and is no help in getting to the next part of the game. The big bro is calmer but takes initiate when needed. Also, a lot of the puzzles involve playing to each brother's strengths. The only thing the little bro can do is sqeeze through tight spaces, but the big bro can operate levers, lift things, carry the little bro while he's swimming, and ward off wolves. In the narrative, almost everything is from the little bro's perspective.   Basically, little bro is the 'main' main character and big bro is someone you depend on. Being an oldest child, I find this a little exploitave, but whatever, it's done well. Most of the early puzzles start with big bro taking initiative and hoisting little bro up somewhere so that he can return the favor. There are a few later moments where little bro carries the load but for the most part, big bro does the work. In the end when big bro gets dies (oh yeah spoilers btw), the powerlessness of little bro is really felt and the bursts of strength at the end are made all the more powerful by this.   There's a phrase thrown around a lot creative writing, 'Show Don't Tell.' In games, you can take it a step further and say 'Do Don't Show.' The final moments of the game serve as some of the best examples of this that I've seen so far. The time the game takes to make you understand the reliance little bro has on big bro is done through all of the same-y puzzles and little cutscenes where big bro knows what he's doing and little bro follows along. In every interaction and ambient moment, big bro presses on while little bro acts childish. A few moments are taken to address little bro's coping with loss and his internal feelings, mainly during the scene where his gaint mom watches as big bro strangles him for concievably being the one at fault for their mom's death. A rather touching moment is displayed when that ends and is revealed to be big bro saving and comforting him. No words (at least not any real ones), and yet everything is made very clear.  There's a battle with a giant spider and a seemingly endless ending (like Lord of the Rings), and in the ending there's a part I mentioned where big bro dies. It's pretty sad, but it's truly heart-wrenching when you have to take the time to bury him. Little bro is very slow and weak, and it takes forever to drag him over and bury him while little bro sobs. It's almost like you're the bad guy for moment, making him bury his brother, and that part will stick with me. The redemptive scene afterwards where little bro learns to swim and does the puzzles on his own are all the more powerful when you use big bro's controls to help him. It's a clear understanding of the influence big bro had, and frankly it's genius.   Now with all I have just said, you might think this deserves that Overwhelmingly Positive review it's got, but here's where things get shady:  I was content to call this my new favorite game until one moment took me out of the experience. After you leave the town with the help of some Orcs, you start trekking up a mountain. On the way up there's a small area where a man is attempting to hang himself. If you act quickly, you can stop him. You do this by having big bro hold him up and little bro climbs up to untie the rope. Afterwards, the man falls to the ground and weeps, saying nothing at all, and does this permanently. All the brothers do is give him a pat on the back and carry on with nary a bit a dialogue. You can also look around in this little area and see a burnt house with the man's dead family burnt to a crisp. Now it'd be a tragedy no doubt if the brothers watched a man hang himself, but I think it's WAY more ♥♥♥♥ed up that they stop him and leave with no condolences. The man is just left there to wollow in misery over his now non-existent home. At least later when big bro died, little bro had some closure with the burial. But no, this man's dead family isn't as important, so we must move on. It's almost insulting that immediately after this part, you encounter a looney dancing scientist who charitably gives you a hang-glider as you fly off to more adventures. It's a drastic and really unnecessary shift in tone.  The next chapter in the game is the Shadow/Colossus part where you come across the aftermath of a battle fought by huge soilders. It's grim and bloody and serves as a definitive shift in tone for the game; you're away from home, you are no longer safe. It would have been a great transition if it weren't for the attempted suicide mere minutes ago. The game progresses a bit more and you come across a woman about to be killed. You save her and she helps you for a while. She's almost Superwoman with her strength and agility (kinda wasted by the fact that she only helps you like 2 times) and a bit of character comes out of big bro as you get a little sense of romance between them. This leads to big bro's only real slip-up where he opts to follow the girl into a spooky cave rather than go where the cure for his father is. Considering everything the big brother has done up to this point, I think it's against his character but it's not quite a deal-breaker like the suicide man. This leads to the woman turning into a spider and big bro getting injuried, which leads to that ending I like.  The reason I hate the suicide man so much is that it brought up a thing that the game was doing the whole time; being emotionally manipulative for no good reason. It's either Disney-levels of happy or gut-wrenching sadness, with no real resolve at the end. Sure, Lil' bro becomes stronger and stoic like big bro, but that was just for the sake of one happy moment. Remember the most recent Tomb Raider where they tried to make Lara Croft relatable by just beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of her? Same thing here. I didn't actually like little bro, I just felt sorry for him, even with the ending.  I guess if a game gave me that much to talk about, it deserves a recommendation, but only barely.

My first negative review on Steam; that alone says a lot about how much I didn't like this game, I think.  Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is very pretentious and serious about itself, it touches some sensitive matters like death, love, fear, friendship and treachery. But it presents all this things so bad, it isn't even funny. It's like a low-grade TV soap opera with really bad actors. Just painful to watch and play.  Characters are not likeable and don't evoke any sympathy. Gameplay is repetitive. Controlling two characters at a time is somewhat interesting idea, but puzzles built around that are trivial.  It boggles me how much positive reviews this game has! How is this possible!? I wouldn't have written this review in the first place if it wasn't for the fact that it seems everyone on the Internet thinks the game is great and wonderful.  I played to the end, hoping to find even the slightest thing that would touch me and make me like this game, but I didn't find anything. The only things I _really_ liked were beautiful scenery and architecture.  In the end I think that overall pretentioussness and cheesiness killed the game for me. I would have even tolerated the not very interesting but good enough gameplay. But the plot and the characters are the core part of this game and you can't ignore them.  I suppose developers worked hard on this game and tried to make it good, but, sorry, I just can't recommend it to anyone.

I love Gone Home and Dear Ester and tend to enjoy platformers and pretty, somber things, and from what I'd heard I thought I'd be really into this short/sweet experience. Unfortunately, there's not much sweet (or effectively somber) about it. The game's tone switches from 'adventure!' to 'prevent a survivor from committing suicide' to 'adventure!' to 'free a maiden from a somewhat offensive spear-weilding tribe' too often, and not with the art that allows better dramas to make you laugh, cry, and laugh again.  The problem, I suspect, is that the game offers up very little to think about as you blindly push Forward from setpiece to setpiece. The world is full of sadness and loss, clearly meant to echo the loss of the Brothers' mother and the potential loss of their father, but there's rarely much commentary or depth to these scenes, just flavors of loneliness. Then, when the game abruptly moves on to riding mountain goats for fun, it's clear that the action scenes don't serve as meaningful counterpoint to the sadness you keep being witness to. During these patches of straightforward nagivation puzzles, there's simply not much to think about. The relationship of the brothers doesn't change, nor do their fears or hopes. They're curiously static against a constantly changing backdrop of sadness and lighthearted adventure. It's hard to put into words, but the game's insistence on dwelling on the world's misery without considering it more deeply makes the whole experience feel like spending a room with a person in the middle of a bad breakup: neither insightful nor very much fun.

I had high hopes for this game. Even some of my favorite video game writers chose this to be GOTY.   I was sorely dissapointed. Perhaps it is my own cynicism. Or maybe my high-hopes were to blame. Either way, I have little doubt the advocates of this game will disagree with me and down-vote this, but I think another opinion should be shared on this title. I was unanimously dissapointed with the areas all the positive reviewers raved about.  The story it tells is generic and bland. It does a good job of telling it, but that hardly makes the story itself any better or worth hearing.   The controls are not 'cool and innovative'. I think 'different' is the nicest way to describe it - other choice words would be 'Wonky', 'terrible', 'infuriating', or 'irritating'. After a few hours of play time, I may be more effective at using them, but it hardly makes them better.  I heard the art praised by many. IMO (Isn't this all? It is MY review...) The art seems to be bland, flat even. Additionally the fidelity leaves alot to be desired - it clearly a (last gen) console game.  The soundtrack is fairly decent. As I mentioned before, the storytelling is quite good, though I believe making the characters mute would have accomplished more dramatic effect than the mumbo-jumbo type noises they make.   I picked this game up on the steam sale for 75% off I believe. I would wait for it to be a $0.99 game before recommending it. At the end of the day, I feel like I've played this game before, many times over. If you're looking for a console port game that is great with a controller and gives you an AWESOME art style, I would point you over towards 'From Dust: an Elysian Tale'.

I honestly do not understand what the big deal about this game is. I have not finished it, but I have played more than 90 minutes (according to most gameplay time I think am at around 50% of the game). I will try to be as objective as I can about the merits and the flaws of this game so far. The game starts with a simple, not-very-touching-but-okayish intro. Truth be told, the atmosphere got me. It was nice and smooth and fairytale-ish. The first thing I noticed which I really appreciated was that they opted not to have the characters speak in any language, but instead using random phonemes that resemble speech -- reminded me of Legend of Zelda. The atmosphere remained beautiful throughout the game, and is possibly the only really good thing about this game, in my opinion.  The second thing I noticed about the game was literally in the first 2 minutes. 'Do I really have to just sit here and keep control and space pressed simultaneously for about one minute without doing anything else?'. Yes. Apparently, I did have to do that in order to lift an elevator. This particular 'Is this really what I have to do? Are you kidding me?' feeling has kept accompanying me for the following 90 minutes. This game literally takes zero skill and zero thought. Don't get me wrong, I may be a hardcore gamer but I always appreciate games that are simpler gameplay-wise and emphasize more on other elements. However, this game overdoes it with simplicity and is boring to death. Most of the time you will just find yourself pressing one button per minute, here and there you will have to keep two buttons pressed at once for a few seconds. Sometimes I honestly felt like I was guiding two physically and mentally challenged kids. 'Go on boy, climb that rock. Yes. Good. Now climb that other rock. Good job. Now let's walk on that ledge'. Let's take Trine and Trine 2 as an example so I can further prove my point. Those games have a nice storyline, FANTASTIC atmosphere, but still they require skill and puzzle solving. They're not just a one-trick pony with their fantasy graphics and atmosphere. Brothers, on the other hand... I honestly felt the need to press more buttons, do more things other than walk and climb rocks and walk on ledges.  As far as the story goes, so far - I repeat, at 50% of the game - I don't think I have ever really felt emotionally touched. I do not believe what some other people have mentioned, that whether you have a brotherly bond in real life or not plays an important role in the way you perceive the game emotionally. I have 4 siblings and I have very strong bonds with all of them and lots of childhood memories with my closest brother. I never felt a 'brotherly bond' coming off the two protagonists, nor did I feel like 'Oh wow, this makes me feel as if the older brother is my brother and the younger brother is me'. Other than that, I don't know, I just feel like there's no real plot, let alone emotion. I could get more feelings by reading a 3 paged kids' fairytale than I have gotten from this game so far.  I still have the curiosity to see what the ending's all about though, so I will update this review once I finish the game.  From my current experience with the game though, I repeat: No clue why everyone is so attached to this game and why it's considered so great. If you want a game that requires any semblance of skill or hand-to-eye coordination or mental challenge, stay away from this game. You will find none of the above.

Good graphics and great imagination/art direction. More of an interactive film than a game. Since it's being sold as a game, though, I'm going to review it as a game: extremely linear, extremely simple 'puzzles', frustratingly difficult controls. Can't recommend.  Story is a big part of games, yes. In the case of Brothers it's about the only part of the game.  When you're creating art, one of the most important choices you make is what medium to create it in. You consider the advantages and disadvantages of each format, and choose what best fits your goals. If your goals are for a person to sit there with minimal effort and thought so they can consume a good story, you should not choose 'video game' as your medium. These people did. They could have chosen to make a great short film - instead, they decided to make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ video game. Don't buy it.

Extremely overrated.  The story has nice ending that's maybe very moving for somebody, but its completely undermined by the whole game before. Two brothers running around and solving ridiculously easy coop-like puzzles, that's more suitable for point&click adventures like Goblins. Locations change each other only for the sake of presenting new stunning landscape and doing nothing story-wise. The whole game wraps it up in ~4 hours and maybe you won't be able to notice any flaws, but for me the whole experience was so boring, I was shocked, that in reality it took so little time.

While this game is gorgeous, probably one of the most beautiful games I have ever played, the gameplay is easy as hell and the story is short, lackluster, and even slightly pretentious. The story doesn't really focus on character interaction so much as fitting in those sad feels every once in a while and in the end it just tries to make you sad with very little meaning behind it all. This game is very much like a painting where they splash paint onto a canvas, it's pretty to look at but there's not much you can do with it and it has no real meaning behind it either. So if you like pretty art then sure, buy this game, but if you like videogames then I would not recommend this.

The good: -The art style and execution is well done. It's like Fable or Overlord but with a bit more of an artist's eye applied to every environment. Even the animations are usually very good. -There are very few indications of what you have to do. The game trusts you to figure it out, and the design is straightforward enough that even with almost no prompts, you'll know what to do and how to do it. -The narrative is effective at tackling rough emotional topics with honesty and sincerity, and the relationship of the Brothers seems genuine and relatable.  The bad: -It's rarely a game. It's almost a shame to see all that great art in a game like this because it could've been used so much more in a game that took advantage of the assets fully. The gameplay of Brothers consists primarily of 'Go here'. Like an extremely watered down Prince of Persia, but without any of the guessing / decision-making about how and where to platform. There are a few moments where there's an actual gameplay aspect to your interaction, and it's like a breath of fresh air. In my opinion, that's really sad. -I am extremely annoyed by the voice acting. The characters in Brothers speak jibberish, and even the non-verbal voiceovers are done in a way that's really overreacted and cheesy. I would rather them be perfectly silent. -Stupid representation of females. Every female in the game is based on an extremely overused, cliche trope about women, and as a couple of the major plot points depend upon those cliches, it left them feeling very hollow and stupid.  The neutral: -You'll never quite get used to the control scheme. It's not a big deal, and I appreciate how they used the controls as a contributor to the narrative. But at the end of the day, it's hard to use, which can't be a positive thing.  Summary: It's a really short game that's not very fun to play but pretty art. If you wanna take an artful journey, go ahead. If you want to play something that's fun, look for that somewhere else.

A Tale of Two Sons probably isn't for everyone and certainly can't be considered serious gaming.   The game is linear, third-person, and difficult only because you control one character with the left stick and the other with the right stick. There isn't much meat in this game with only 12 achivements and 4-6 hours of play time.   There is zip dialog (we'll cure the foreign distribution and language issue by using grunts and gestures while avoiding the expense of voice actors). There were other aspects of the game that suggested that it was made on the cheap like an invisible NPC, crude graphics in one chapter, limited camera angles, poor proportions for some items, etc.  Achievements really aren't for merit or difficulty. They seem like an after-thought and more related to finding Easter eggs in the game than showing any skill or working out anything difficult.  There is no plot beyond a quest to get a magic item to save the boys' dad, After all the trouble, there is a disappointing ending that presumably was to make you feel sad and think that doing good requires sacrifice or some such.   It had some high points like flying a glider, but the mean average is below zero in my oipinion. Basically this game is as flat as a pancake when it comes to excitement. Not sure I would recommend it to anyone. I'd give it a PPPfffffpppptttthhhh rating.

Useless waste of time. No real story to speak of except for a very, very superficial premise and the token MacGuffin-Chase. Crummy control concept which gets even shoddier with a keyboard, a camera that does whatever it wants, NO PUZZLES (!) whatsoever, long stretches of gameplay which is in reality an extended cutscene where you hold down a button/trigger or push an analog stick in one direction - that's it! The wannabe-emotional and hamfisted tear-jerkers strewn about are so hollow, they're ridiculous.  Art direction, animation and character models are nice enough on their own, but not enough to redeem this game. In turn, the music ranges from 'crap' to 'barely mediocre' and the sound effects are unimaginative and lackluster.   This game would've been interesting for an hour or two back when gamepads with analog sticks were new. WOW! You have to use both of them at once! Press the triggers and move the sticks around! Sometimes even in a circle! Incredible what can be done with them 'contrulars' or whatchammacallit. This is the equivalent to the first Kinect or Wii games, clumsily trying to find a purpose, a justification for their control mechanism to exist. But it fails miserably.  Not worth more than 2 €, the time you waste you will never get back and there is nothing redeeming about this pile of garbage.

People tend to write thousands of words to describe and review video games. This one doesn't need that many.  Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a very powerful 2-3 hour experience that involves the player in much more than just pushing buttons... even though technically he IS just doing that - pushing buttons. The plot is nothing new at all, but the way that it's told is fairly unique. It's a game to be experienced, not read about or watched on YouTube.  I too could write a thousand more words about this masterpiece, but I'm convinced that knowing too much about this game would take away from it (which would be a horrendous crime). Friends of puzzle/adventure games should definitly have a look at this game. It's not very challenging as it's not trying to be, but any story - be it in a game or any other medium - that makes you care so deeply about characters you've only known for a short while and who barely even talk (in a language the player doesn't even understand and has to interpret!) deserves one's attention.  If after reading this you still want more information to make an educated decision, there are plenty of in-depth reviews about this game to find. Just be aware that they might tell you things you would have prefered not to know in hindsight.

I am one of the people that rarely plays adventure games that require fighting or using avatars to interact with anything. I purchased this game because I saw it when it came out in '13 and the story was a good one that caught my eye. I was surprised at how they avatars worked together to get solutions to problems and I am really enjoying the game. I do not own a controller yet, but I will by the end of this week.   I found the game to be short, somewhat easy as I am not used to controllers and a keyboard is not easy to use, but can be done. I read a few reviews before buying the game, but I had intended to buy the game anyway because of the story.  The music was very well done and not repetitive. Usually on a game, I would turn the volume down of turn off the music, but in this game, the music helps to set the mood and is just as important in gameplay as anything else.  The opening sequence is very important. The first time I watched it, it took me by surprise. I won't ruin it by going into it, but It think it will be better to day that this is a game about a story and the story is quite emotional if you get involved into the game. I did. Bring tissues.  Take to time to admire the scenery. The artwork is...breathtaking! I buy a lot of games for the stories they tell, but rarely do I get a game that the story and the graphics are on the same or better par than anything I have ever seen. And the characters are almost lifelike in their attitudes and actions. As an example, I sat the younger brother on a park bench and watched him play for a few minutes. The younger brother's movements were so lifelike, you could almost think it was modeled after a real child.  I have to say, I rarely buy games of this type, but I am starting to think that I may have missed something by not playing them. This game may get me into playing more. I would also like to mention that this game is one of the cheapest games that I have purchased for my PC, but it has a permanent place in my library and my heart.   Buy this game. It needs to be played and enjoyed. Not everyone will 'get it' or really immerse themselves into it. Those that do not will miss something. I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone.

Brothers: A tale of Two sons Review  There are games that exist merely with the intent of making us feel like the ultimate bad ♥♥♥, there are games that test our reflexes and our minds, and then there are games like Brothers: a tale of two sons. An emotional adventure that has sealed a place in my hearts with its brilliant sets and memorable characters. Let’s take a look at this little masterpiece.  Story.  Brothers: a tale of two sons is a story about you guessed it brothers and their quest to a magical tree that holds the antidote to their father’s illness. Armed with nothing but a map and each other, these boys set off on a magical adventure that takes them to a strange land where it becomes clear that they don’t quite belong. You can go ahead and argue until your blue in the face about silent protagonists and how they are old fashioned and how you can’t get an emotional connection with the characters if they have nothing to say but that’s just untrue. These two boys show more emotion and character in a few hours than most triple A protagonists do across an entire series. The amount of emotion expressed in each movement and each grunt and nonsensical language they speak, speaks volumes to their personalities and thoughts. I can’t overstate enough about the emotional impact and will delve deeper in my story review but the tale of these two sons is one story I won’t be forgetting anytime soon.  Gameplay.  As far as the Gameplay goes there’s not much to be said here. It’s your typical puzzle solving gameplay where two protagonists each with their own unique abilites help each other through varies situations. The catch this time is that each of the brothers is controlled by an opposing analog stick on your controller. Being the uncoordinated ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I am I did find the control scheme to be quite bothersome at times. Having the wrong brother running ahead while his younger sibling is plowing into a wall can be frustrating at times but luckily there isn’t any platforming that needs to be so precise that this becomes to much of an issue. As far as the actual puzzles go there isn’t anything too complex but I will give credit to the section of the game where you are roped together with your sibling as easily the highlight in the gameplay category. All in all the game is fun to play even if it is annoying at times.  Presentation  The world that Starbreeze Studio created for this game is emaculate. The amount of mystery and wonder behind each section was breathtaking. I kept wondering to myself as I was playing, what’s going on here, what are these guys doing, what kind of creature lives here?” the entire time I was playing. The art direction is fantastic even having spots where your character can sit down and enjoy the beautiful scenery. From great mountain views to creepy castles all the way to terrifying caves. The diversity in presentation is something to admire in this title.   Brothers a tale of two sons is an experience very little games these past few years that I have played have been able to accomplish. The amount of emotion put into these characters and the journey these boys go on is a one of a kind experience that no one should miss out on. Tale of two sons is a crowning achievement in the study of how games can offer a one of kind story telling experience that can not be matched in any other genre.
Interesting gameplay mechanics, great presentation, and an emotionally driven plot. Though the experience lasts for a short while, you won't soon forget it.

I bought this game while on sale for less than $2. I was looking for a story driven game, and this seemed promising with the 'overwhelming positive' reviews....and of course the price. As almost every other review states, the game is short. I finished it in less than 3 hours (that is without going out of the way to get all the achievements tho). I wish it was longer but I wont knock it down for that.  In Short:  The technical parts of the game, like controls were good, but story-wise....eh.  I was dissapointed in the story and the feels aspect of the game.  Its not a bad game, I just didn't think it lived up to the hype.  But maybe its just me tho, I am not really the kind that looks very deeply into art.   I would say that this is an experimental game. Not in a bad way but its kind of a niche in my eyes.   Can't say I would really recommend it unless its on sale. This game is a hit or miss....it was a miss for me sadly.  I wanted to like it.  In Long (that makes sense right? lol):  Graphics are fine, nothing to complain or praise about. (as long as the graphics are decent it really doesnt affect me).  Controls are a bit weird, basically, the right side of the controller controls the younger brother, and the left side controls the older brother. And often you have to control them at the same time, so it can get confusing. BUT they did a good job so that during important parts its easier to control and not confusing, they did this by either having you control one brother at a time or by force aligning the brothers so that they are on the same side that their controls are on (Older brother will be on the left side, which matches his left side controls). So basically dont worry about raging due to the controls. I give them credit because the amount of controls is low; 1 analog stick for each brother and 1 button for each brother, 2 buttons for camera movement, and the start/pause button. So 7 in total, but you'll mainly just use 4 lol. But even with the simplistic controls you do a large range of activities, so it doesnt feel like your input to the characters is limited.  This game consists of puzzles, none of which I really found that challenging though. And there were a couple times where I'm thinking 'why dont they just do this instead, and just avoid this problem all together?' or 'how come that person doesnt just help us by doing exactly what they will do later but just do it NOW!!'. Some things i also just found silly, or some things they did just would never work. Some of the puzzles can get a bit repetitive. But thats me being picky. The game is for really casual play.  There is no understandable dialogue. The characters speak to each other, but its some language not known to our world. Which is a cool idea that i respect, and one reason i find this to be an experimental kind of game. BUT i feel that the lack of dialogue made it so i didn't connect to the characters as well and I felt it left out the details of the story. The overall story is easy to follow and understand without the dialogue, but i would have liked some more detail, personally.  The environments you go through are quite nice and i like some of them a lot. As well as interesting creatures.  Replay value: Low  Honestly, I'm mixed on whether to press the thumbs up or thumbs down for this. I wish their was a sideways thumb option. lol  Conclusion:   Its an experimental game that, in my opinion, does some things right and some things wrong. Its unique and i give it a lot of credit for that. But i guess it just didn't live up to the hype for me storywise, i didnt get all the feels most people seem to be talking about. If you are curious, like experiment games, like real casual games, or want to be a game dev, then get Brothers while its on sale. Otherwise...look somewhere else. I had heard positive reviews of  Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons  but avoided learning too much about the game. Having played through it now I think I can safely say that part of allure of this game is discovering the tremendous environments alongside the characters. There were many occasions where I just stood there panning the camera around to enjoy the world.  I won't spoil anything here - gameplay is quite linear with simple puzzle solving. The primary mechanic being using a single controller to direct two characters...simultaneously. This isn't particularly difficult, but it does create some interesting mechanics and the odd time when you switch places on screen but your thumbs haven't figured that out yet. The story is remarkably well developed given that there isn't any understandable dialog (any communication is gestures and intonations in a made up language). Relying on the situation and subtler details to convey love, loss, urgency etc draws you in that much more effectively. Start to finish gameplay is quite short, about 3.5 hrs depending on how much you like to stop and look at the scenery.  I thorougly enjoyed my playthrough, but there is nothing there to draw you back for another journey. Consider the shortness, lack of replayability, but very satisfying visuals and story to decide what value you might place on the game. At typical sale prices I think it is definitely well worth it.

This game gets a recommendation from me, but it comes with a number of 'buts' attached.   What does the game do right?  It shows off a nice looking world, it tells a story without any English dialog and it does single player co-op in a slightly different way. The puzzles are all straightforward and take advantage of the control scheme offered.   What does the game get wrong?  Strictly speaking, nothing. It does what it sets out to do, but I believe it could have done things differently.   Should I buy this game then?  Sure, you should, as long as you're aware that the game is quite short and quite easy. Buy it at an appropriate price.   So, if it doesn't get it  wrong , what could it have done better?  That's where there's a lot to say.  First, a small thing, graphics wise. The bloom lighting is just a little bit too much in a few places. Besides that the graphics are superb.  The biggest and most glaring issue that I have is with the tone of the game. I won't spoil anything beyond the first five minutes of the game - you're a pair of brothers on a quest to get, uhh, a something to cure a sick man who we safely assume is your father (the story telling is very minimalistic, we'll get to that). It would therefore follow that the tone of the game is one of urgency. But that feeling is entirely lacking.  What's worse is that the things that make this game interesting pull HARD against that sense of urgency. Right at the start of the game, as you go through the town where you live, there are different interactions per brother with the townsfolk. A lot of the atmosphere of the game is discovered by interacting with everyone at least twice.  There are also different ways the brothers interact with their surroundings. One brother plays in the water, the other drinks from it, etc.  Then there's the nice scenery. See a statue, walk up to and interact with it, the camera pulls down and shows off the details. There are even benches where you can sit, which moves the camera to a 'beauty shot' angle.   All of this completely takes away from the tone of urgency. This conflict in tone really took me out of the game. On the one hand I wanted to appreciate all this detail and work that went into the landscapes, the character interactions, etc, but on the other hand I felt like there was no driving force to the story.  I'll go onto the story then, more specifically how it's told. The characters don't speak a real language, so we hear a few semi-words repeated a lot. This minimalism is both good and bad. You certainly follow the story, but it's not a terribly deep story.  One brother recieves the majority of the character development but altogether it's very limited. And the story telling, perhaps because of the minimal nature, leans on cliches and tropes.  Finally, the puzzles and controls. Before you get to your first wall-climbing puzzle the game feels VERY grounded and realistic. I very much enjoyed that. And then the brothers are indivudually leapfrogging up walls, able to scale heights taller than they are, only a moment after a puzzle where one has to boost the other to climb a much shorter ledge. That also took me out of the game and felt jarring.  The game play is linear and pretty easy; you can't go the wrong way, you can't fall off ledges, though you can let go at the wrong time and fall to your death. The good puzzles are, unfortunately, towards the beginning of the game. Later in the game there are more wall-climbing puzzles, including a new mechanic that only adds to the unrealistic feeling that these puzzles create.  The game is basically on rails. Yet most of the time you feel like it isn't, and there are sequences that are VERY on-rails (the glider in particular) where you still feel totally in control and the game comes together beautifully.  And that's why I recommend this game, despite the clashing nature of certain aspects of it. The game presents a story that you can follow, makes you feel like you're mostly in control of it, and does so with nice graphics and controls. The game is both deep in detail and story and yet shallow in the same respects.

Brothers, A Tale of Two Sons - An Commentary  Controllers are the nexus of the the game experience, they stand at the intersection of gamer and game. Countless innovations on the controller’s design and implementation have been applied to gaming over the years. One of the most common questions game developers are confronted with is, “How do we map our controller?” In a small Danish game studio a new improvisation has emerged, providing a new paradigm for the conventional controller. In “Brothers, A Tale of Two Sons,” the controller is used in ways that exceed the standard user/avatar UI of typical role playing games. The controller functions as an inherently deep gameplay element and a powerful story metaphor for an experience of cinemagraphic emphasis. The narrative itself is simplistic, but effective, it’s minimalist approach is reminiscent of Danish 30s cinema. Ironically the game was made by the Danish Starbreeze Studios. Nothing is used unintentionally within the game’s design, this is true for all the elements from props to plot devices. The logical progression behind behind the game is clear cut, the desires, ambitions and fears of it’s characters all have causes, achieving a flawless parallel between plot and theme. One of the unique strengths of a minimalist narrative with no intelligible dialogue is that it takes away the premonition that the player can control the dialogue. This let’s an aspect of the narrative that cannot be influenced fade into the background. In “Brothers a Tale of Two Sons” by Starbreeze studios the controller is not only used for its typical interface between player and avatar, it is a story metaphor. The story itself clearly illustrates the dynamic features behind the relationship of the brother. It reinforces the story’s base narrative and operates seamlessly within the metaphors of the story. It demonstrates the reliance of the two brothers on each other during navigation and puzzles, the player being a single essence provides the uniting features of these notions, this is hammered in through the steep learning curve of controlling both characters simultaneously. The artifacts of this design choice are seen in simple plot devices where the player must give up control of the younger brother so the older can carry him through the water, and in the more sophisticated puzzles where communication between the brothers is paramount. It is always difficult to quantify emotional impact. In this case however most of the story’s weight branches from its basic narrative and the functional weight of the gameplay system. This may seem obvious, but within interactive media the term “basic narrative” is rarely seen. This particular game thoroughly engages the player through all the senses it has at it’s disposal. Visually it bares a system that places an emphasis on story elements and lets all else fade into the background. It’s soundtrack is both compelling and beautiful. The controller provides excellent tactile feedback. The metaphorical system on the controller is not only symbolically correct it provides a brilliant area where the affection of the characters can be betrayed. The controller splits vertically down it’s middle, the left side corresponds to the older brother the right side corresponds to the younger. This creates a geographic expression for the two brothers’ relationship which is not only fantastically metaphorical, the player comes to love being the means to the brother’s relationship. We see the organism of the game as an extension of ourselves. This is all an elaborate setup for the butchery of this organism, when the older brother dies the player's connection to the story is cut off. The player feels the loss and seeks comfort with the only individual that can relate to her/his plight, the younger brother. This leaves the player as an engraved element in the story’s structure when it ends, the end of the narrative leaves the player unfulfilled. The death of the older brother brings out some of our darkest fears as humans, it reminds us that even in an interactive game, just as in life, we have no control over death. The player realizes that in spite of his/her governing power over the brother’s relationship, they can only implement the choices the characters made for themselves. When the voice of the older brother returns at the resolution of the story, the player watches as their control disperses further as death, an element totally out of their control as humans, once again takes the wheel. In Brothers, A Tale of Two Sons, a fixed narrative is presented, using emergence strictly as an utility for enhancing the experience of the game. The most unique element of the game is it’s use of the controller as a story metaphor and tactile plot device, reaching beyond the utilitarian design scheme of the conventional game. This mechanic fits flawlessly into it’s minimalist visuals and compelling soundtrack taking the gaming community on an emotional rollercoaster they won’t soon forget.

Short but sweet, this 3 hour adventure achieves what it sets out to do; deliver a bittersweet and emotional narrative via some great visuals and interesting puzzle mechanics.  The puzzles don't pose any difficulty, but are varied and fun enough that they don't get boring. The short length of the game is a positive in this instance as I feel there are only so many ways to skin a cat (apologies if this grim idiom doesn't translate well to other languages...) when it comes to a lot of puzzle games. Another aspect that helps to alleviate any boredom from lack of challenge is the visual side of things; the art direction is pretty impressive, and although these are clearly not 'next gen' graphics the world is certainly beautiful / fantastical, and there are many places to sit and admire the view.  There is no dialogue as such (they speak a less annoying version of 'simlish') but there are still some interesting characters to meet, and some fun little secrets to discover as well.  All in all, this game does what it does well, and doesn't outstay it's welcome. Not for absolutely everybody - those not interested in story-focused games, or might be put off by paying for only a 3 hour experience can move on. Other than that, pick it up in a sale, play it in an afternoon / evening, you will most likely have a thoroughly enjoyable time.

Definitely good changes in atmosphere. Main characters are brothers who I assume intended to one day join the circus given how athletic they are. Achievements are neat hidden things to interact with rather than just stuff you do for beating the game, they also let you put an end to bunny prejudices. Mix of emotion with areas. (Some more adventurous areas are shown to be exciting or joyful but overall the game has a sad overtone to most of the interactions you see.)  Cons: Controlling two characters at once can get confusing. Makes you feel like an idiot when you forget which stick controls which brother and you end up running into walls. Some graphical bugs, shadows in some parts would overlap in a weird way, textures for things that collapse didn't blend well sometimes, and occasionally around cutscenes there would be black silhouettes of where the character models would eventually be standing. The strongest emotional response I've had playing a game, is in Brothers.  You traverse the world in unison. Together you'll solve simple puzzles and explore cobblestone villages, dingy mines, and a crystalline arctic ocean. It is beautiful.  The brothers' story is told without words we understand. We become familiar with them through their actions - one uses a lady's broom to dutifully sweep the porch, the other cheekily shows off by balancing the handle on his palm.   When you first control each brother with their assigned analogue stick, it is awkward. Janky and disorganized, you stumble over obstacles. You're uncomfortable - just as the brothers are uncomfortable working together - they've never had to. But as you improve at the pat-your-head-while-rubbing-your-belly controls, so do the boys. They begin to cooperate. It's this progress that highlights the bond they establish with one another as they forge ahead. It's the second best example of control mechanics having narrative purpose in Brothers.  The best instance, will simply leave you speechless.

Excellent little title. While the 'game' elements here are relatively light, by way of being short, leaving you kind of wanting them to be a little bit more elaborated upon, the unique character control ideas and truly excellent narrative more than make up for it. Starbreeze put an interesting spin on what is actually typical 3rd person platformer fare with the simple yet genius idea of two simultaneously controlled characters in a single-player experience. It's a bit of a shame that the small-scale indie nature of the project in conjunction with the game being focused on story means that these sequences are relatively short and take a back seat to the unfolding narrative. This leads to the actual gameplay ideas explored to feel more touched on than fully fleshed out. While this by no means makes them or the game any less special feeling, if you're looking for a challenge, you might be left wanting. The actual world presented and the story one is allowed to experience are top notch. While there are no understandable words spoken throughout, the game does a tremendous job of communicating what is going on with the characters to the player and involving the player in it all. In fact, the whole game feels a little more like an interactive experience than a typical videogame by virtue of the gameplay elements working to bring the player into the world to allow them to experience the journey, moreso than serving as a real challenge. That said, it's not that there is no challenge at all; what is there is provided by the disorientation resulting from having to control two characters at once, and this can be quite fun. The world itself is quite whimsical, yet also reserved in the use of outlandish fantasy tropes. This lends quite a unique and mature feel to what otherwise feels like a game adaptation of a child's fable a la the Brothers Grimm. Graphically the visuals don't really have much to commend them on. Instead of attempting to go for flashy the developers went for competent. While the game doesn't look impressive, the visuals themselves are adequate and look good. The artstyle itself is not particularly flamboyant or colourful either. Rather, think nordic minimalism. Everything feels lovingly crafted and subdued, nothing is superfluous. This, again, seems to be so in order to allow place in the centre stage for the actual adventure the two characters share. And what an adventure that is! The game being as short as it is, it's hard not to spoil anything by discussing details, so I won't. Suffice it to say that the journey that Starbreeze has fit into the rather short 5 to 6 or so hours of gameplay is really quite the epic and one of the best and refreshing in modern gaming in my humble opinion. Do take into account that the shortness of the experience in this case is deceptive as it is packed with content that should be able to truly touch anyone who plays this. Highly recommended, especially if you're getting this for your kids. This is the best answer yet to the saccharine world of dumb entertainment available to children these days.

First off, I played the entire game using just the keyboard, no controller like it states you need on the store page. I can't imagine it playing better with a controller, anyway. The gameplay may be a little awkward to begin with as you control the movement of both characters simultaneously (one brother is controlled by the WASD keys and the other, using the arrow keys). Yet, what was initially awkward only became increasingly enjoyable once I began to appreciate what the developers were trying to achieve.   The unique gameplay, detailed sense of atmosphere and a few interesting puzzles is really what is on offer here. The story is relatively straightforward and is mainly conveyed through action rather than dialogue, as the game displaces verbal speech with exchanges of gibberish between its characters, similar to way language is used in say, The Sims. The effect is something exotic and unfamiliar if not distancing, but it is successful in conveying a sense of belonging and place for its main characters.   There's quite a fun journey to be had here and a few surprises throughout even if nothing is explained but more to evoke a sense of atmosphere and history more than anything else. Oh, and be ready for a good time, just not a long time.

It allows for a full-scale exploration, but certain features are still limited to only going along with the story.   You really connect with the two characters, and as you play you see how they grow and develop as a character. It feels weird, when one is missing and the game will always remind you of that, considering they can't move or go on without each other. We don't understand the language they speak, but we can still see it through their actions and expressions. You don't see much games in the market now, that is simple and have a plot that you can follow. The plot is rather simple, with the two brothers searching for a 'magical' tree to save their father, but it gets more in-depth as you go along and see their past. You don't see much other characters, due to the fact the game is mainly centered around the other two, and the amount of people are also limited to a small selection.   Overall, it is one of the best games I play and I would recommend you to buy it, during a sale or for regular price.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is not just a game, it's a wonderfully crafted emotional fairy tale and an amazing journey. The controls in the game are very easy to get used to; you control two brothers, each has its directional keys and an action key. On the Steam store page of this game it says “Notice: Brothers – A Tale of Two sons requires a controller to play”, but that’s not true at all. The game is perfectly playable with the keyboard. You can also play the game in co-op with your friend on one keyboard. Game mechanics are very simple and basic too; you'll mostly pull levers and solve simple platforming puzzles using both characters at the same time throughout the game. Even though the game has simple controls and mechanics the story, atmosphere, characters, the world around you and soundtrack are simply perfectly put together and those elements are where the game really shines. With all those elements combined the game evokes certain emotions in player through the whole journey and that’s the game’s strongest point; to make you really feel and care for the main characters. Through prologue, 7 chapters and epilogue you’ll visit various places with beautiful landscapes, environments and aesthetics. The only downside of the game for some people will be the fact that you can finish the whole game and get all achievements in 5 hours, at least I did, but even though I knew the game was short from other reviews and first impressions that never made me disappointed or not interested in this wonderful game. Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons is an amazing experience that you'll finish in one breath and I would strongly recommend it to everyone.

If you have doubts about playing the game, stop and play ! You won't regret

Brothers-A Tale of Two Sons is an adventure game where you play as both an older brother and a younger brother who are desperately searching for a medicine that will cure their sick father. There is no dialogue in the game, but you are able to understand exactly what the brothers are 'saying' when they are communicating. As you play through the game, you will begin to notice the strengths and weaknesses both brothers have. I won't spoil anything, but as an example, the older brother is blinded by his attraction to young beauty and the younger brother will do some stupid things sometimes, such as knocking something over when trying to sneak past a sleeping giant. Brothers is one of those stories where you are always surprised by what's around the corner. The world you step into is full of fantastical creatures, odd rituals and scary moments. It shows the connection 2 brothers can have with each other when it really matters. As a younger brother to a sister, I can very much relate to what the protagonists can do and will do to protect their sibling. The visuals of this game are amazing, from looking over massive mountain ranges, to creeping through small caves, you will be astonished in how good this game looks. The music is great! It's timed at the perfect moment when you enter a certain area and it never gives anything away. Finally for the verdict: Brothers is an excellent game full of heartbreak, action and surprises around every corner, it will blow you away with it's excellent movie like visuals and gameplay, along with keeping you guessing with it's soundtrack. I would pick this game up any chance you get. 10/10 in my eyes.

Lovely little gem. Short and easy with few puzzles requiring more than a cursory glance to solve, but almost every puzzle sequence is a new unique take on its gameplay mechanics, so it feels much more varied than one would at first expect it to.  It helps, of course, that it features highly (and increasingly) varied areas with a fairy tale aesthetic to both its light and its dark passages, intriguing mysterious backgrounds to what exactly happened there and rather breathtakingly beautiful vistas.  And most of all, its story is amazingly well written in its minimalistic presentation, relying heavily (and surprisingly well) on its core mechanic of one movement stick and one action button per brother to tell the story to you through your own (partly optional) interactions (although there are in fact several short scripted cut-scenes, mostly serving as scene transitions and/or as most - but not all - of the emotionally really big moments), with relatively little dialog in its made up language that however transports the feelings appropriate to any particular moment perfectly. At times heartwarming, at times heartbreaking, at times both at once. Just lovely. Seriously, do not read spoilers!  As for the achievements, they are all little optional side-quests rewarding kindness and/or playfulness, some lying directly in your path, some requiring a little bit of exploration the few times it's actually possible. Same goes for the many benches you can sit on (with either one or both brothers) to really appreciate a select number of panoramas.  Also, it plays better with a game pad (particularly when needing to turn something in circles), but the keyboard works decently enough, so a controller is in fact not required to play.

The game is well-paced all the way through. The puzzles are not overly complicated but not too simple either. The gameplay is challenging without making you feel like controlling the two brothers is overly frustrating. There are no active-time button presses or any other cheap gameplay mechanics. Every part of this game feels well thought-out.  You will need a dual-analog controller and I highly recommend the Xbox 360 controller. If you have an issue where the older brother's controls are reversed then see the Steam forum for the quick config edit to fix it. Overall, a very fun game.   The ending is powerful and emotional in a way that is moving and deep. Very few games have had this kind of effect on me.

I went into this game knowing only that it implemented a non-standard control scheme. However, what I found was not just a gimmick but a well-rounded and polished game. There is really no part of this game that I disliked. The art is unique and beautiful, and with the camera allowing you to fully take in the scope of the scenery. The world is populated with interesting creatures and people, both in design and in action. The world of these two brothers is both vibrant and disturbing, and despite the small personal story being told, you really get a sense that there are much larger events taking place in this world.  Despite no understandable dialogue, you really get a sense of characterization of the two brothers and how they are different. As well, their relationship and love carries through. Drifting too far away and having them call out to each other feels genuine. The story is a relatively simple one, but it is executed very well. And without spoiling the story, near the end the control scheme really moves away from gimmick and becomes woven into the story seamlessly.  I really enjoyed everything about this game. The music and sounds were haunting, yet fit perfectly with the atmosphere. The variety of set pieces for the different chapters really showed off a great deal of variety. Even the achievements are not difficult or lengthy, but merely require taking a few seconds to explore the depth of the world.  I cannot recommend this game enough. It is well worth both the price and your time.

Very mixed feeling. I really would like to see more narrative-focus adventure games being made, but Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons just didn't feel like a game - more like an interactive film (more so the fact it's so short), and not a very good one at that.  Visual and audio directions are amazing. That plus the emotional ride mentioned by other positive reviews kept me playing. Unfortunately the adventure didn't live up to its hype. The control scheme is interesting but felt it wasn't fully explored in puzzle design. Puzzles, if you can call it that, are way too easy and feel more like a distraction.   There are a lot of interesting places and characters, but the game never give opportunity to explore and learn more about them. So the adventure ended up feeling like a dream. It's emotional at times but like a dream it's so random and moves so fast that in the end you weren't sure if it was a good dream or bad dream, but it leaves you feeling melancholy.  If you like that sort of feeling, definitely play this game. Otherwise I wouldn't recommend it.

First, the bad. This game has no dialog, and I did not find that artistic, different, or at all engaging. The lack of real language did not bring me 'closer to the emotion' or any such thing. It was just plain annoying and brought the level of the whole game down to a more cartoony, childish experience. A little time spent on some sparse voice acting would have done wonders for Brothers. I did not really develop an attachment to the characters, and without giving anything away let me say.. the ending scenes would have been much more effective at drawing out emotion if the two brothers were not so flat, and maybe a verbal que existed to tell me what the heck I was supposed to do..  Now, the good. The scenes were very well done, and although a lot was left unexplained that is not necessarily a bad thing. A richly detailed world fiction describing past battles and current world politics is something that would likely be ignored by most players (myself included) anyway. Creating huge, dramatic scenes and leaving me to wonder what the heck is going on around the two brothers just made those scenes more interesting and drove my imagination. Everything was beautiful to look at and the story was charming, at least what can be pieced together without dialog. Level design was always interesting and I was never bored. Some of the extra things you can do on the side were also pretty neat and unexpected. I really liked the disparity between the two brothers' personalities, how they interact with things differently.  I would not hesitate to pick this game up on sale. I did, and I don't regret it. However, if I had paid full price I would have been disappointed.

This game is both a joy to look at and to play. Despite knowing it'll be free on the PS+ network next month, I bought it during the sale and even 75 minutes in, I don't regret it. I expected to be frustrated by the 'single player co-op' as the game calls it, but the controls are intuitive and the puzzles that involve both brothers make sense. Even if you don't know precisely *how* to do something, you can tell exactly *what* you're supposed to do at a glance.  As a puzzle platformer, it's probably very easy. But it's not about that. It's about the bond that's built as you play both of these brothers, interacting with each other and their environment. Like I said, less than 2 hours in I already feel a deep sense of attachment to them. I find myself moving the older brother first, to protect the younger one. But the younger one is always the first to interact with new people, because it feels like it's in his nature to do so.   With no dialogue (that you can understand--though context is easy to read here), this game relies on action to tell its story and reveal the personality of the characters, and so far it's done a phenomenal job. Highly recommended.

Perhaps one way to become attached to two video game characters simultaneously is to control both of them at the same time. They rely on each other, in ways that you grow accustomed to.
