There is a spark contained in Brothers that is all too soon over, and if ever the consideration was to make an extended edition, I would more than happily endulge.   The moments spent in Brothers are always thought provoking. With areas that are gorgeously lit and rendered, it's easy to see why the characters rest on benches provided along the way. Eye candy galore, and an exceptionally paced transitions of environments left me wanting more. No matter the locale, everything had the undertone of a story that took place before the brothers visited it. Perhaps if I were to replay it, I would analyze the stories untold and then perhaps have a better sense of this game's world.  Inginuity makes every moment exciting and rewarding, but ultimately in the end, as it gives you a profound amount of respect for the story being told. I couldn't think of a better reason for feeling a connection to the two brothers, and I hope there are more impactful stories to come.

This game is like an interactive movie. Playing the game is not difficult at any point, the player needs to do very little to get the reguired outcome (usually just move next to an interactable object and press a button) and most of the 'action' parts are very pre-scripted. There are puzzles along the way but they are very simple and easy. There is very little exploration involved and you can't really change anything about the story or events.  The reason why I would recommend this game is that the things it does (above I tried to say what it doesn't do) it does very well. It shows this remarkable world in a very beatiful and deep way. Even though most (if not every) of the wonderful little things about the world are very common in many fantasy settings (like trolls, magical trees, etc.) this game presents them in a magical way that I (a grown-up) felt like a little boy who is introduced to possibilities of imagination for the first time. I played this game through in two sittings but would have played it through in one if I hadn't had to stop playing during the first time I launched the game. It truly was like watching a good movie, I didn't want to stop wathcing until it ended on its own.  I personally liked the concept of playing in coop with myself. It was on the other hand kind of sad that the possibilities it can open weren't fully explored. I'm sure that there are people who find these 'difficult' controls to be a turn-off but anyone willing to keep an open mind should find out that it works well. I personally was very surprised how well the camera was able to follow the protagonists. I very rarely needed to adjust the camera manually.  Another thing that this game does very well are the achiements. Usually achiements in games are gained by just playing the game. Nothing extra is needed. Just by finishing the game you get something like 80 - 90 % of all the achiements. In this game you will get 0 %. They are all kind of like 'side-quests' that you end up completing just because you were so drawn into the world that you wanted to interact with it and its people/creatures as much as you could.

Brilliant game! The atmosphere is amazing, reminds me of Journey in a way.
Hands down one of the best games of 2013. An emotional adventure that grabs on to you and doesn't let go even after the credits start to roll.

it takes just 4 hours to play the whole game but every minute of it is really amazing. the controls are very simple (just 1 button for every brother and 1 control stick for every brother) but its still a tricky game because sometimes you have to think what to do and sometimes you have to be skillful with your hands. this game is really something very different on the video game market and its imho a must have for every true gamer.

Quite possibly my PC GOTY candidate for 2013. What a beautiful, amazing game. Yes it's short. (3 hours), but can be purchased for $5 on sale. The artistic design, the story, all were excellent. Definitely recommend it to everyone. I just wish it was longer, as I enjoyed the ride.

Absolutely one of the best adventure games I have played. The experience of playing with a controller and control the two brothers was superb. Controls are meh, but presentation and environment are well worth putting up with it. Would recommend at full price, would definitely recommend on sale.

This is a great game, although maybe a bit overhyped. It is roughly 2.5 - 3 hours long. For me, the controllers were a bit difficult as each control stick controls a separate character. So every now and then I'd find myself running into walls as my brain tried to figure out which character matched which stick.  The story is the entire point of the game and it is a powerful one. After you've finished make sure to think back on all of the different elements of the story and what they mean. There is a certain fight that seems out of place until you realize that even that has a lesson to teach.  Take your time and enjoy the game and scenery. For me, its worth around $5-$10. There is no replayability in this game though, so three and a half hours would probably be the max amount of time you'll get out of this one.
A great exprience that made me shed some tears and one of the best games of 2013.
I love this game! Gorgeous graphics, beautiful music, cute characters, original and fun gameplay as well as an emotional story. Everything I like in games is there!

Are you a man enough dude to control two people at once?!   Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, follows in the footsteps of short art/story games like LIMBO (Brothers is only 3 hours long at most), or even something like ICO, with puzzles, mystery and beautiful visuals. As the title entails, you play as two brothers in a fantasy world full of giants (or maybe you're just dwarves), and other fantastical things, who are on a quest to find an elixir to help cure their father of whatever ails him.   If you haven't watched the trailer or read anything about this, the unique part about Brothers is the control aspect - you control two characters at once either with the joysticks (recommended) or on the keyboard. While this is certainly something very different, the implementation was a little bit weak, with the puzzles being very easy to complete. The main difficulty of the game most derived from actually co-ordinating yourself - only times I really got caught up was when I used the wrong hand. In addition, there isn't really any punishment in dying, though I suppose the point of the game was otherwise.  The most stunning part of the game is definitely the visuals, and the developers know it. I don't think I've ever seen a group of devs more in love with their game than 505 - they even provide park benches throughout the game for the player to take in the scenery, and rightly so I might add, since it is a beautifully stylised game. In addition, they have paid attention to detail on a bunch of little things, like footsteps in the snow for instance, which is nice.   Music was quite nice, and really suited the game well. Dialogue on the other hand was just jibberish, and while I completely understand that they were going for a story that was communicated visually (and there wasn't any problem with their execution there), I believe that the lack of proper dialogue reduces the ability of the audience to connect with the characters.   Speaking of which, the story and setting of the game was quite astounding. I myself was expecting a more lighthearted game, but it actually is very grim and dark, which was surprising (in a good way though). Also, despite my criticism of the dialogue previously, I did like the vagueness of some parts, as it preserved a sense of mystery about things.   So in conclusion, I found this game, despite it's short length and ease, recommendable because of it's story and beautiful visuals. It's nothing to pay full price for (I made that mistake with LIMBO), but certainly something beautiful to pick up and have a go at when it's on the cheap.  PS: The moral of the story is 'bros before hos'.

This game is just, wow. Like a good book or a good movie, you immerse yourself into it. It doesnt need no flashy mainstream gameplay/music/characters. This game is humble and sound, and is perfectly executed.

This is one of those rare games that, while very short, leaves a lasting impression. The story does a lot with very little. You don't need crazy amounts of dialogue or things pointed out to you here. The game shows you what you need to see and keeps things moving along at a nice pace. Don't go into this game looking for a challenge; there is none. Don't expect a lengthy adventure as it is only 3 hours long if you take your time. Do not dismiss this game as a child's game simply because it has a whimsical graphical style. This game ventures into very dark territory that many games shy away from. The controls do take some getting used to, but there aren't many moments where it can really get in the way. This is one of those games that really can be considered art, and even without the sale price is well worth admission. Do yourself a favor and play this game.
On par with Ico. Fantastic game.
A beautiful and heart warming game, with a story perfectly told in a wonderous and breathtaking world.

'Short, but sweet' is the best way to describe this game. A very unique puzzle game with an emotional storyline that speaks louder than words...which is ironic given that there is no actual dialogue in the game.
Beautiful beautiful game with an amazing world design - highly recommended
A realy beautiful game.

Play it! It's easily the best game of 2013 and one of the most beautiful stories ever told in the videogame medium. You owe it to yourself to play this. Don't check reviews, don't see YouTube, go into the game free of prior knowledge and enjoy one of the best experiences videogames have to offer.

I read about this game about how it was beautiful with a good story and it was more than that.  The gameplay is very smooth even though you have to control 2characters at the same time (xbox360controller highly recommended) The environments are beautiful, the lighting even more stunning. Nothing in the game feels like a drag or makes you wonder 'Why would I need to do this?' no, everything is just fluent and even though the characters are speaking a made up language you feel a true connection between them and you kind of get attached to them which causes emotional effects during certain times in the game. Could be even greater with local multiplayer option. It worths anyways
Amazing, beautiful little game, simple and yet challenging at the same time

'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' is a game that is quite hard to describe. How would I explain to a friend that a game that is easy, short and made by an indie developer actually deserves more spotlight than a triple A title? Well, all I can say is: I can't. This is a game in which there is never ever a single comprehensible word in the dialogs, but is still able to make it completely understandable through wonderful body expressions from the characters. Everything in 'Brothers' screams simplicity, but at the same time it touched me in a way that very few games did. The way the game takes you through this world of strange creatures makes you feel like you were in a true and genuine adventure. The design is simply stunning, making me feel as if I was staring at a painting in every location throughout the journey. The end literally made me cry, which is something that never happened to me in any kind of media. Add to that an incredible control scheme, which consists of you controlling a brother with each stick of the controller, and very clever, but easy-to-figure-out puzzles, and you have a masterpiece.This is surely one of the best games I've ever played. Masterpiece/10
Short, but nothing less than an amazing storyline.

The control scheme is rather unique, there's some gorgeous sights, nice little moments,... it's not very long, but it's a qualitative experience for sure and worth the price. Get this one. It is a stunning game that has a really interesting mechanic. It truly deserves a visit by anyone who is interested in a light hearted adventure with interactive puzzle elements. It truly captured me for the first hour and i only stopped playing do to an error that shutdown the game for me.  Recommended.

Very impressive game. It grabs you and doesn't let you go away from your PC until you complete it, which doesn't take long time to do so. Great.

Never mind shooting guns, exploding barrels, stabbing blades and annoying AI (Skyrim :p)  This game may only be around 3 hours long,  but it will have you interested to the very end.  9/10

The core of the game is the simultaneous control of 2 characters... the brothers obviously! It lets the player experience a very innovative approach to the fantasy adventure genre. Some backgrounds are overwhelming! The only flaws I unfortunately have to mention is the lack of content and that most of the puzzles are way to easy to solve... but if you like fantasy movies and games where the player also has time to relax, this is definitely the right pick for you. COD players should keep away from this :p  I would rate it 7/10
Wow, what an awesome game, a little short but well worth playing. I hope to see more of this type of game coming out, very clever concept.

Hands down the best game I've played recently. To me, it's a plus that the game only lasts about three hours. Worth every minute spent in it.

irritating to master controls, but worth it for the experience. without a single word spoken a truly great story is told.

What can I say that hasn't already been said, this game is the next step in storytelling, the visuals are right at home in the setting and story and the soundtrack is subtle and ambient. This game has changed the way I look at games, if you have 15 bucks to spare you owe it to yourself to play this game.

While this may not be the best 'game' I've ever played, I am certain it is the finest interactive entertainment experience I've ever had. It also happens to be the first time I've ever had a 'this could only be achieved in this medium' moment. Heartwarming, heartwrenching, profound, excellent.

The whole game only takes about 2-3 hours. The puzzles are fun and clever but not really difficult. It's the bond between the brothers, and the plot twists, that really make it worthwhile. It's really just a way to tell a story in a clever way. It gets pretty dark at the end, and there's a few 'feels' moments when you get near the end.   If you don't care for stories about loss, emotion, and family interaction, you probably won't like it. But if you like clever use of simple mechanics and an emotional story, it's totally worth it. Aside from learning to control the game using a thumbstick for each character, the difficulty is fairly minimal.  The story is great though. Regard it as you playing along with a brilliant story, you're there for the ride. The payoff is definitely worth it.  OH! Before I forget! My first playthrough was a co-op run with a friend that has spent much of her life unable to enjoy gaming. With half of the controller in each of our hands, we managed to clear the entire story together. Needless to say, both of us were blown away by this game. Secret co-op mode is totally worth it!
It's not so much a game, as it is a story. This is what a short story would look like in video game form.

Short but sweet is the theme of this story. It takes not but three or so hours to complete, but what you do complete is one of the best stories I have ever played. Im not going to spoil anything except that this game is very emotional. The puzzles are not that difficult, but do a great job at showing that the two brothers have to be as one. Looks great also. This game is something everyone needs to play.

This is one of the most beautiful games I have played in a long time! The whole envorionment is so breathtaking and the game knows it too, they put in benches that you can have the characters sit on just to gaze out at the world. The gameplay is great too, while it might seem simple as there are only four buttons to use, a set for each character, the interactivity of controlling two characters at once and independent of the other works marvelously. I could go on forever, but you should just play the game.

I used a keyboard and got on ok, but the game controller is recommended. It's not a particularly difficult game nor is it long. As another reviewer put it, it's not about the destination, it's about the journey. It's the story that it builds up and demonstrates the bond between brothers. A truley amazing visual experiance, the world is beatiful with an art style that really compliments the games universe. The gameplay is also unique experience but this game must be played with a controller.
By far my best game experience of 2013. Simply stunning. Superb story enhanced by game controls. (xbox controller required)

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons - If you play this, which I highly consider you do, prepare for an emotional roller-coaster. As far as story driven adventure games are concerned, this is the cream of the crop.  The gameplay revolves around the interaction between the two brothers with each other and the world. You control both at once using controls that at first seem quite gimmicky, but as you get used to them they are simple, they work, it gets the job done. They must overcome obstacles and solve puzzles by working together to achieve their goal of finding a remedy for their sick father.  the world itself is beautifully designed, some absolutely stunning visuals. the story is short, I finished it in around 3 hours for the main story, but if you take your time and discover all the secrets maybe a bit longer, but it surely leaves a lasting impression because it isn't afraid to go to some dark places but also knew when to highlight a truly joyous moment. The way it achieves this is by guiding you through this guiding the player through the special moments instead of just showing you a cut-scene. it is evident the developers wanted you to fully interact with the story through all parts, this is especially obvious near the very end.  overall, an incredibly impressive game for such a small one, and i would fully recommend anyone to play it.

Absolutley brilliant. But other than that minor niggle the game was way up in my top 3 games of this year, if not 5 or 6 years, possibly longer. I would reccomend that you set aside 2-3 hours to play through the whole game at once though. I think you will get far more out of it by doing that.

Fresh new type of game that I have never seen before, and it is nice to see a game that is different.  Cons: Short...very short. Finished in about 4 hours, and that includes all but 2 achievements earned. Replay value is low IMO. Very little to interact with in the environments.  Summary: Game is great, and would highly recommend if you are looking for something fresh and new. Good story, game-play, and controls. Can't see how someone could play without a controller, but the controls are good using my Xbox 360 controller.

This game is a wonderful tale more fucosed on story vs. gameplay with a deep story which I found myself relating to regularly despite being a rich story it did have a lot of rich game play with fun puzzles and games which can only be carried out with the control of both brothers making that a unquie and exteremly satisfying when complteting them. I rate this game a 7 out of 10 because on its fun puzzles and controls of the brothers and rich story but it falls in the length of the game feeling slightly rushed and cut a bit short.

interesting platformer. player uses both control sticks to guide a pair of brothers on a search for some type of magical water that will heal their father. while 90% of the puzzles are an absolute breeze to figure out, the game is fun to play through and the graphics and music are sublime. i would love to see a zelda game with this art style. don't spend more than $15 on this one.
Brothers has given me the most profound emotive expereince I've ever had from a game. It's amazing. Well worth playing to the end for yourself. One of a few games I would recommend to nearly anybody.

Nice game, good mechanics and looks really nice. good set peices and good imagination.  But only 4 hours long, an overly dramatic story that does not grip, about 5 puzzles in the whole game, its basicly just a platformer only you can't really fall off.  The music is boring and the voices are annoying Also no collectables, no difficulty level or modes so no replayability at all what so ever.  Pick up in a sale for about 2 pounds, not worth more.

I was an emotional bomb that exploded in the end.  GET IT, IT'S WORTH EVERY PENNY!

Game is a bit on the short side, clocking in at around 3-4 hours for me, that's including the time it took to get all achievements. On that note it has 12 extremely easy achievements and chapter select so they are not really missable! Good game, worth picking it up if you find it on sale. 7/10
Like it very much. Great game.

This is easily my game of the year. I beat it in about 3 hours, so it is short. But the game's story melds with mechanics perfectly. I laughed, I cried, I was scared, and most of all I had a blast.  Can't recommend this more.

One of the few hidden gems in the steam store that is a must have. A visually stunning presentation of two brothers working to get the water of life to save their dad. This game really comes through with using music and images to deliver an emotional experience while still being entertaining at the same time. The controls are easy and intuitive. Worth 14.99 all day.

Cinematic Platformers are brewed slowly and with love. This game is a superb cinematic platformer with a unique approach to using the 2 brothers. I have been playing it with a USB Xbox Controller and it's just plain fun. The puzzles are hard enough to keep you amused for a while, then turn hard to master and become VERY rewarding. The most rewarding part of solving puzzles fluid and sequentially is in fact the Visuals! Visually it's a gem, it is also a gem when it comes to Narrative. If you enjoyed Eric Chahi's 'Another World' or Oddworld's Inhabitants you will enjoy the gameplay. It reminded me of ICO also. I loved this game.
The game is amazing. Couldn't go to sleep until I finished it.

The most incredible story driven game I have experienced so far. The most important thing I have to say is that you need to cherish your time within the world that has been constructed and immerse yourself. This is a brilliant example of how film and video games can mix together to make something hauntingly beautiful and truly unique.
You just have to play it to see.
A beautiful, moving game. Short, but memorable!
This game... I have never experienced anything like this in the video game medium before. This is a game that you will never forget playing. 10/10

'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' manages to leave some kind of a fulfilled feeling behind, like no other game has done for me so far. As long as you have a controller, you should give it a try.  Beautiful graphics support an outstanding storyline. With some confusing and odd moments, there is still always a reasonable explanation not far away. The controls are extremely well done, serving as more than just a means to control the game (you'll understand this, if you complete it). While other games try to be story-driven, this one accomplishes combining all aspects of a game to create an experience around the story.  My advice: Buy and play 'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' to completion, you  will not regret  the time you spent with it.
completely worth the 2-3 hours it takes to complete. absolutely a great game. buy it, grab a controller, and thank me later.

A brief review of 'Brothers: a tale of two sons'  'Brothers: a tale of two sons' is a game developed by Starbreeze studios and published by 505 Games. To play it you will require a compatible game controller such as an Xbox 360 pad. This is for a rather unique game mechanic, controlling the game's two main characters at the same time, big brother and little brother (they do both have names but I could not remember what they are to save my life). You control big brother with the left stick and trigger, then the little brother with right stick and trigger. With the two brothers you will be doing some puzzle platforming. This mostly consist of making the two brothers pull levers in sync or carry an object together. The puzzles are easy to figure out, its just getting the brothers to work together in order to complete them. I can almost guarantee that more than once you will get a little confused and make the brothers run in to a wall or fall to their death, but When you do successfully get the brothers to work together it is extremely satisfying.  At the beginning of the game you are shown that your mother has died and your father is dying, you take your father to the town doctor to find that the only thing that can save him is the liquid from a far away 'life tree'. From then the brothers embark on their quest to find the tree. The game looks fantastic in the graphical department, which helps to create a colourful and vibrant world. On your quest you will find benches scattered around, I highly recommend you sit on them for a few seconds so the game can showcase some amazing vistas with its awesome art style and graphics. There is no denying that the game is a bit short (I finished it in about 3 hours), but it is definitely worth your time and money.  ***SPOILER ALERT FROM NOW ONWARDS*** IM ABOUT TO SPOIL THE ENDING SO PLEASE DONT KEEP READING IF YOU HAVE NOT PLAYED THE GAME. Basically spider-woman comes along and ♥♥♥♥s everything up. She stabs your brother as he kills her (which admittedly is a pretty cool twist). From here on out you just play as the little brother, you manage to obtain the life saving liquid but it does not work for your brother and he dies. The scene where you bury your fallen brother is very well done and pulls at the heart strings of the player. You return to your father and save him with the liquid, I guess it only works for people who are dying but are not dead. I’m not really sure how to feel about this, you save your father but the player does not really have any bond with him (not like to big brother). I am not saying that the ending is bad, it just feels like the big brother died for nothing as the player has no idea who the father is and why the brothers would risk certain death so many times to save him.

Gameplay- Though the puzzles are often not complex, they serve to develop a bond between the brothers and the character. This bond in turn, constructs an experience unlike any other.  Story- Though this story contains tropes familiar to the average person, it somehow transforms that into something deeper. Due to the length of the game, it would be difficult to explain further without ruining some of the experience.  Value- The value in Brothers does not lie in the gameplay. If you are looking for a lengthy game with some 'meat' to it, look elsewhere. If you are looking to take explore the emotional depths a platform such as video games can provide, look no further than the 'Add to Cart' button.

For months I kept hearing about this game from various sources, all of whom said it was emotional and moving, etc. After putting it off for as long as I could, I finally caved and got it when it was on sale. My expectations were that it would probably be another sweet, simple game that tugs lightly on your heart strings, but ultimately forgettable. This is where I say that I was wrong; Not only was it emotional, but I'm not ashamed to say that it brought me to tears by the end. Which is a surprise for many reasons, but the biggest being that I generally don't shed a tear for anything, especially a work of fiction.  All you need to know about the story is this: There are two brothers that set out on a perilous journey to collect the sap of a magic tree, which they believe can heal their dying father. As the game is rather short, saying more would likely spoil some key moments. There are some surprisingly dark tones and imagery, which at first caught me off guard, but it's clear they are not simply there to be edgy. Everything has a deeper meaning, even the controls (I will never think of the left trigger the same way again). The music is excellent and emotive, and the developers use it at the right times, with the right level of intensity. The main theme, especially the acoutic version heard during the credits, is still swimming around in my head as I write this. And It is worth noting that all dialouge is expressed in a fictional language; You won't understand what they are saying, but the characters use expression so effectively that you will begin to realize that you do.   I don't want to oversell it, but saying that I recommend this game isn't enough; It doesn't give it proper credit. It's titles like this that naysayers are clearly not paying attention to when they argue ignorantly against those of us that believe video games are, or can be, a true form of art.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a good game that you should try if you really hate your fingers. The game starts you off in a way that gets you the hang of the dual analog functions. Even people who use the gamepad a lot will start the game off feeling a bit strange. Not long after the start, 15min, it will feel like the only way this game should be played.  The story is about two brothers that have a sick father, Aeed and Aada (At least that is what it sounds like their names are) want to save the life of their father by going to the Tree of Life. On their journey you will come across obstacles that will sometimes require only one brother, but most of the time two will be needed. You will fly, swim, climb, defeat bosses, and swim through pools of blood through the story. The pace is kept at a constant and even though it is only a few hours long, you will not feel like there was anything missing. The ending, like many have said, is very good. That is all you can really say because it will only impact you if you go in without knowing the ending.  Art wise this game is up there with Journey, Killzone 2, and Super Mario Galaxy. Snow, trees, rain, and the like all have a distinct look that seemlessly blends together when traveling.   The textures are sometimes extremely bad, but the game easily hits 60fps on a 1GB HD 7850. The lighting and shaders are very good and make up a bit for the lackluster textures.  The soundtrack is also very good with no dubstep in dramatic moments unlike some recent games.  Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is something everyone should make the time to play, preferably in one sitting.

Masterclass. This is not a game designed to be fun, it simply takes you on an adventure in a way that allows you to establish a connection and relationship between a number of characters in a story told by gestures, vague vocal exchanges and the environment.  The textures, lighting, shading, camera angles, environment design and interactions are pristine. Despite some people describing this game as having puzzles, the solutions are so easy to intuit that they're mostly intended to be flavoring for the adventure rather than work your brain. They're clearly trying to tell a story as smoothly as possible, not throw roadblocks at you.  The only issues I had were a single bug that a restart fixed and there was an important voice recording that lacked a level of emotion necessary for the scene. The voice overs in general were kind of generic, though satisfactory and not distracting for most of the contexts they're used in as no words are spoken. It's not as much of an issue until emotion is important in a scene and the voices don't convey that.  Overall, the game is very tastefully creative. The creativity doesn't blow your mind so much as it impresses you that they invested the effort to bring you that experience. There are subtle surprising progressions as things go from run-of-the-mill to wild over the course of the game. Take ICO (minus the flaws), smash it together with some vague Journey inspiration, give it charming visuals, a touch of Tomb Raider and maybe throw in the occasional overlooks from Assassin's Creed by way of benches you sit on and you have Brothers.  As most of the story is told through brief interactions, it's probably best to interact with each thing in the game using each brother to see as much of their personalities as possible.  I laughed a few times, though it's not trying too hard to be funny. Cranked the music in a few spots, but the music doesn't steal the show. It's a linear game telling an extremely simple story that takes a short 3 hours to complete, so there's no need to rush through it. It works with keyboard, but a gamepad is worth using.  Similar to Journey, it is probably best to play it in one or two sittings, keeping the entire experience fresh in your mind until the end.

When I got this game I was expecting for it to be amazing.... and boy did it deliver. This is definitely my game of the year 2013! I actually don't know which aspect of the game I liked more - the unique gameplay or the wonderful story and the way it's presented to the player.  On the surface it looks like a regular puzzle platformer, but the thing that sets it apart form other games is the fact that you control each of the brothers individually. And that's the thing that makes some of the latter puzzles challenging, since technically they alle are pretty simple. Controlling two characters simultaneously is an odd thing to do. Another amazing aspect of this game is the fact that throughout the game not a single word was spoken to either explain a gameplay mechanic or to progress the story, and jet it was easy to understand what was going on and what the game wanted me to do.  Both visuals and sound of this game create wonderful atmosphere that compliments the emotional story at all times. I wouldn't say the games graphic are anything special, but it by no means an ugly game. Pretty much all environments are nicely crafted and few places are down right gorgeous. This reminds me that I have to look up the soundtrack of Brothers, because some of it's tracks are still stuck in my head.  But I must also warn you of few things that may put a frown on your face. The game was designed with a controller in mind, which is a non issue if you have an access to such a thing, but as far as I know most PC gamesrs do not have them. Keyboard controls work, and you can definitely play the game, but it feels much more organic when it's played with a controller. It also isn't the longest of games. I bet it in about three hours. Which for this kind of a game is just perfect I think, but I also bought it at a discounted price(50%) and at full price I would have probably been a little disappointed. But as it stand it was worth every cent I spent on it.  TL;DR Buy it you dummy! It's amazing!

When I saw 'Control both brothers at once” I thought, “this will be a great co-op game” – I was wrong. When I reached what I though was the end I though, this would be a great movie – I was wrong. Don’t get me wrong, the gameplay is great and two-players is quite possible and could be enjoyable. The story is also just beautiful on its own. But the tear jerking moment when you, alone, reach the end and have to guide both brothers at the same time, the realisation that comes with the fact that you are pressing the buttons, the details like there being two stones to climb at the end (sorry if this gives away too much)… You just have to grab the controller with both hands and try it. When you do, you will understand how much sentiment a single button can convey. Just a further notice, on a more technical side of things, the game warns you it is best played with a controller and while it is playable with keyboard (I played the first levels that way), it is easier with a controller when you have to press several buttons at once. If you can, buy or borrow one and use it. I used a €10 generic one and besides a small documented bug where one of the joysticks had its y-axis switched (something that was correctable if you look it up on google and could probably be from the controller itself) everything went smoothly. Other than that the game is well built, had a few hiccups with animated portions repeating themselves (probably because I kept the triggers pressed during them) it runs smoothly and gives you a short (just the right size) yet powerful story.

Take a deep breath of fresh air, forget all about your English listening comprehension skills, and bring out the tissue box: you're in for one heck of an emotional trek. And by golly, it's a good one.  Let me preface my recommendation with this: you're likely ever going to play this once, unless you play it again in front of your friends purely to make them sob. But don't worry, regardless of if you never play it again, it's worth every single penny you will set aside for Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons. This experience will be with you for a lifetime.  Ever tried playing a video game with two controllers before, just to unlock some sick new virtual gear, or perhaps to beat up your invisible friends because you're just that pathetic? You found that to be really hard to do, illogical and counter-intuitive, right?  Although it seems daunting at first, in Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, you control both characters simultaneously with the one controller. It's stupendously easy to pick up: within five minutes of starting the game, I found myself cranking a dropbridge completely subconsciously. This core game mechanic of controlling both characters is unlike anything I've encountered before, and as it wiggles its' way deep down into the plot, it is one of the very finest mechanics I will ever encounter.  (You'll realise why I'm talking so highly about damned game mechanics by the end of the game. Trust me on that.)  The graphics and music for this game are a bit wonky and average, but I was so compelled by the plot that this took little to no accountability in my opinion of this game. I can genuinely say that you must, and I mean MUST, buy and play this game. Once. For feels' sake. For the safety of you and of those around you. For your health. Buy. This. Game.  Thank you to the fantastic TotalBiscuit for the suggestion to pick it up while it was on sale. I am forever in your debt.

If you are like me, or even some of your interests include: fairy tales, captivating scenery, Scandinavian things, touching stories, not very long games - then this game is for you. As one can see from the revievers' playtime, this game is very short, but it doesn't mean it's lacking. On the contrary! The story may be simple but that's it's charm. It easily kept me interested and I was holding my breath throughout. You'll meet friends and foes alike. Some small storylines made me smile while at other times I was left wondering what happened where I passed along my way. The whole story is visually driven. there's no real speech in this game, when the characters talk it's in a simple gibberish language. The scenery is very beautifully realized. This is a fairy tale nothern style: pretty little mountain villages, vibrant mountain paths can take a sudden turn for sinister forests and unsettling warthorn plains. The whole atmosphere and various aspects of the game very much reminded me of Journey on the PS3. The controls are really well done in this game. You'll need a controller to play it but once you've got one you'll have no problem leading both brothers. There are some very mild puzzles along the game but nothing you'd have to go crazy over.  tl;dr Charming story, pretty graphics, emotional scenes paired with easy and short gameplay.  10/10 - a lasting experience

3D Puzzle Platformer Adventure Game - 9.5/10 - Amazing experience, a must buy   This game is honestly amazing. It is a roughly 3 hour experience (although if you like exploring and bagging achievments then 3.5h), the aesthetic is beautiful, the story is simple but moving and very well told. There are problems with it, at times the mechanics get in the way of what you want to do but overall the puzzles are very simple and serve to pace the story (well). But overall I believe that it is an excellent example of how games can tell stories in a involved way. The mechanics tell the story, the way the brothers interact immerses you in the world. If you haven't already then buy this game.  Although, do note that if you do not own a gamepad or other twinstick controller then you will not enjoy the game half as much as the keyboard controls are sluggish and I believe at one point you are unable to progress without a gamepad.   If you are wondering whether it is worth it for £10.99 / $15 then either:  - Wait for a sale (I bought it for around £2)  - Buy it now, it is well worth it.   Overall an excellent game, if you haven't bought it already then you need to, now.

This game is simply amazing. The characters speak in a language we do not understand and there is no subtitles to tell us what they are saying. This being so the entire story is told through tone and intonation in their voices and by watching their body language. With these two things the story unravels to reveal a story of two brothers setting out to save their ill father with a magical cure that can only be found very far away. Even though their language is not in a tongue we can understand it still has consistencies and if you listen close you can pick up the meanings of words and even their names. The story easily captures your attention with lively characters, the two brothers being drastically different in personality with their own quirks, disadvantages and advantages and with scenery that is simply breath taking. Throughout the game you control the two brothers together at the same time and they help each other get through obstacles and puzzles. You cannot hope to solve a puzzle without both of them working together. The game is relatively short but even in that small amount of time you get to know the brothers well and I dare say, even become emotionally invested in them and their ability to complete their quest. This game is simply outstanding in what it can acheive with so little. I highly reccomend everyone give it a try.

This game has me devided. On the one hand, I was blown away by how the developers utilize the controller to tell the story. Rather than just being an input device, it realized a bond between me and the characters in a way I have never expierenced before. This aspect was so impressive that it easily warranted the purchase by itself. Another positive is the beautiful, diverse world. At all times I would wonder what would lay around the corner.   However, the puzzles are simple to the point of being more nuisance than challenge. What's worse, is that the plot is even simpler still. This is my greatest gripe with Brothers; the story has no depth to it whatsoever. I was expecting more than a simple fetch quest. Finally, the game is very short (about 2,5 hours) with little to none replayabilty.  Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy Brothers. The world is charming and it amazed me how a story can be told through making creative use of the controller; I just wish the story was not so mind-numbingly dull. If you're in doubt: I recommend picking it up on sale.

I heard a lot of hype around this game being the best game around brothers. After playing the game I found that there are still 3 better games about brothers, but this one is still pretty good:  Def Jam: Fight for NY: This game has way more brothers like Snoop Dogg, Redman, Method Man and Ghostface Killah. Super Mario Bros. 3: The brothers in this game can turn into Tanukis and Hammer Bros., something this game lacks. Mother 3: This game about brothers actually made me cry. Their dad is also pretty cool and not a generic sick parent.  Brothers does have various advantages over those other games, like the fact that you are always controlling the two brothers, that's pretty cool, also the brothers are always cooperating in the game, unlike that jerk Luigi using all the stars. The game is short, sweet, and barely has any filler. While not incredibly hard, there is a satisfaction completing one of the multiple set pieces. The game looks decent, although the animations, especially for the emotional scenes were pretty bad (The other 3 brothers game all have superior animation quality to be honest).  The music is pretty good, and controls manage the balance between being tricky, and also being really simple. The story is also simple and emotional, although I would like more world building for some of the areas. I think the stages present well enough the state of the world and the scope of the brother’s journey. In short recommended, although the brothers aspect was lacking compared to those other 3 titles, I just hope someone makes the Citizen Kane of games about brothers one day.

This is a short game, only around 3 hours and I recommend that you play it through in one go.  So its like I said a short and simple but gripping story of two brothers that must travel the world to save their dying father by finding some kind of 'world tree'. You control the two brothers simultaniously with one bumper and a single trigger each(I used an Xbox controller, you can play it on keyboard as well but I prefered the controller)   The game is a platformer/puzzle game where most puzzles demand that you use one brother to do one thing and the other to do another thing, the brothers also got different 'abilities'. The older brother can swim but the younger cant for example.  While the puzzles themselves arent so hard the strange control method makes it somewhat of a struggle now and then. And even if the game can at first can be seen as quite childish I promise that it will touch a few very adult matters.  I actually find it funny, while many games put in massive effort and lots of money to make their games show emotion(most fail btw) this game atleast made me feel both happy and sad at several locations despite its simple nature.

Get this game! Boom! Review done!  This is one of my favorite games, it has everything you need, a good history and SUPERB gameplay. And also the creator is Swedish (Like me), what more can you ask for? That's correct, basically nothing.  Let's get to the serious part...  This is a game created by a famous Swedish film director, called Josef Fares ('Kopps' and 'Farsan' are his most famous movies). You follow two brothers on their journey to find some plants to save their dying father. They meet all kinds of danger, everything from trolls to big spiders.  An interesting thing with this game is that you play two characters simultaneously (You need a controller to play this game, as far as I'm aware), you control one character with the left part of your controller and the other one with the right part of your controller. At first I was a bit sceptic to that mechanic, but then I tried it out, and oh man it works good! To complete the game it takes about 3 hours (at least it took 3 hours for me). It has some REALLY amazing puzzles where you need to control both brothers to continue. You can use a PlayStation 3 controller by downloading some programs (NOTE: You need to plug in the controller into an USB port).  I would give this 10/10, as I haven't find any major bugs or glitches.  To get a more detailed review, I suggest watching TotalBiscuit's review on YouTube.

There is little that is groundbreaking about this story-driven single player adventure game at its core, but if you were to grade it only on subtle touches, it rates a near-perfect score. This fairy tale nestled in a fictional Nordic-like village thrusts you directly into a dramatic story which takes two brothers through a series of puzzles and challenges on their quest to retrieve an item of great sentimental value to a dying man. The puzzles are simple, so the game draws its strength from the myriad wordless interactions the boys make with each other and the world around them, many which are easily missable by those who make the mistake of plowing through the main storyline just to beat the game. The level design and sound are beautiful, and contribute to make a surprisingly moving gaming experience. The only failing is a rather clunky (yet innovative) movement system that requires both analog sticks to move both brothers, which is often disorienting and cumbersome, but all in all, this is a gem that should not be missed.

Played all the way through on keyboard - it is entirely possible to do so, but I ran into issues where I couldn't have them both be holding something AND both go forward. In other directions, it was fine, just forward was the problem. So I couldn't have them both jump up a cliff face in synch, I had to jump one at a time. It also made some of the dual-interaction object manipulation kinda awkward.   ****************Possible SPOILERS from this point on.***************  That's pretty much my only issue with this game. It's a short but bittersweet, mostly intuitive puzzle/adventure. Controlling both brothers at the same time is a challenge, but a fun one! It definitely gets your left and right hands acquainted. And I didn't realize how much I relied on their color schemes to differentiate them until they were both covered in red. Oh man, that was... interesting.  Beautiful scenery and music. There are both humorous and melancholy tones throughout the game. The story progresses through gesture and action rather than dialogue. And then it hits you right in the feels. And I mean  ALL of the feels . I waited for a minute after a cutscene thinking to myself, 'Wait, are they going to make me do this? They're making me do this. Oh god, why?' And then it  keeps  hitting you in the feels as you continue playing until the very end.  Highly recommended, even if you don't have a controller. A box of tissues might be in order as well.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a marvelous game that unfolds itself beautifully with the fantastic settings, the fantastic pieces of music and the fantastic story that involves two boys looking to save their father. I will not spoil the story, so let me just say that this, although rather short game, is so deeply layered that everybody will have a different opinion on the story as a whole. If I might so confess, this game Does bring emotions into the whole mix, and small encounters with different characters can turn into something much greater if you let yourself drift off with the game.  The game itself lets you control two brothers. The gameplay is rather weird, as you have to control both brothers at the same time, each with one of the analog sticks on your controller (yes you must have a controller). While I do say it's weird, I would never say that it's bad per say. Some may enjoy it, I did as I became better and better throughout the game, but others may think it's crap.  One of the first things I praised about the game was the settings. Brothers is truly a tale, like the ones you would listen to as a child, that takes you through daunting mountains, frightening forests, giant castles and many other places. The journey is amazing, especially when accompanied by the amazing soundtrack, the colourful graphics and the lovely characters you meet throughout the story.  I do so recommend this experience.

Sometimes scary, sometimes epic and even funny.  It ist just amazing, that a game with only four buttons can be that exciting to play. ** YOU NEED A GAMEPAD OR OTHER GAME CONTROLLER **  I have to start my review by saying the graphics for this game are pretty amazing.  The game overall is an adventure to help your father, but as you go on your journey, you find yourself as just a small part of the actual world, and in-fact the side stories in the game can be as moving or intense as your own.  The overall controls are pretty unique, and they can take some time to get used to. But once you get accustomed to using both brothers in-sync or partially in-sync, it's pretty interesting. The game is based off two different controls for each brother - moving (using the respective joystick), and interacting (using the respective trigger) - as well as camera controls.  For people who play for achievements, unless you look up the list and try for them, you'll probably complete the game without getting a single achievement.  For re-playability, it's amazing to play through the first time. The second time would be great for getting the achievements. Aside from the story, there is no reason to re-play after completing the game.  Overall, I would highly recommend this game. It plays like an adventure game with puzzle elements (but I wouldn't call it a puzzle game in itself).

'BREEEEEEEEEEEEEEE DEEEEEEEEEEDLEEEEEEEE DEEEEEEEE I'M RUINING THE MOMEEEEEENT BREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE'  That said, I'd still recommend it. A must buy, great unforgettable experience. Won't find another game like it.  Just played this through today, really enjoyed it and thought it was a fantastic game. The game uses a simple to grasp yet continously entertaining system of an anolouge stick for each brother and an action button for each. It can be a challenge not to mix the controls up since you control the brothers simultaniously.   The puzzles are not overly challenging but they do well to keep the game moving along at a comfortable pace without ever leaving you bored. The interactive world around you will have you exploring the mostly linier world and seeing all you can do with the Older Brother usually being mature while using the younger brother to cause mischeif and laughs! The story is truly brilliant in how enjoyable it is and fluently it blends into the gameplay. You never lose control of your characters for more than a few seconds, making you feel very involved in the story as the characters you play.  I think most people will attach themselves to one of the characters as themselves e.g the eldest sibling being protective of the younger sibling, never letting him stride too far ahead of his little brother.   Cliffnotes:  -A fantastic and memberable story that makes you feel very involved through its gameplay.  -Fun mechanics that don't feel overused as the game changes up even the simplest of obstacles as you progress. -A pleasant interactive world which will leave you wanting to explore every nook with and how you can affect the world around you. -Single Player Co-op style gameplay which thrives on the dynamic and relationship between the characters and leading to some enjoyable game mechanics which aid in great fun instead of gimmicks.

As I begin this review, it is 1:54 in the morning. The entire upper half of my face and my chest hurt from the excessive sadness I have just felt and been exposed to. And I sorely regret getting all of the achievements in the first run through because all I want right now is a reason to play this game again. Immediately.  Like the other reviews say, this game is kind of short. My first real playthrough was maybe somewhere around 5+ hours (and I very much took my time). My hours on record lie- I had Steam issues and had to start over from being about halfway through, and I accidentally have left Brothers open for at least four or five-ish hours.  Now, getting down to the actual content, I have to first say that I honestly saw the ending coming a mile away. And then I accidentally saw a spoiler that confirmed my theory when I was nearing the end. This did not at all soften the blow or lessen my experience in any way, so hey, MAJOR props to this game and the people who put it together. They really know how to design and I am thoroughly impressed. This game's dialogue is nonexistent- the characters communicate through very purposeful-sounding gibberish, but they have very clear, deliberate story and emotion behind them. That's one thing I absolutely applaud about this game, and I think it was a very smart choice. For me, no actual voice acting using a current language could possibly trump this unusual but very fitting and beautifully executed method of communication. The controls are very simple and easy to pick up on, and thanks to the really awesome design of the voice acting, anyone who speaks any language can probably play this game just fine.  A very important note- expect some dark themes in this game. It's not a fluffy adventure thing where you always feel triumphant and justified. This game doesn't care about your preconceived notions of traversing and saving the world with two cool brothers. It just does not care.  I played this game on my PC, using the keyboard. I was first trying to play this game using a controller, but the controller wasn't cooperative. I do indeed understand that this may have somehow made the game not as fantastic for me as it was for others, but despite maybe making some maneuvering tedious, I don't really see how a controller could make Brothers any better than it already is, so if you're more comfortable with a controller or a keyboard, I say stick with it. But if you have access to a controller, definitely give it a whirl and just feel it out for yourself which method you prefer.  Two notes I want to stress about this game (the second one I didn't really bring up above): - It is emotional and beautiful and its core idea and communication of are absolutely brilliant. I  love  the story aspect of this game. - You will see some things that may make your eyes roll into the back of your head, like a patch of rock that is a bright white sort of color, compared to the darker rock that makes up the entire rest of the wall, a turtle you somehow can't pick up because it's too close to the edge of a rock wall, a rock with a pitch black shadow, some absolutely asinine deaths on occasion for absolutely asinine reasons. These are mild and the game is very forgiving with its checkpoints and overall puzzle-like gameplay. Don't let this stop you from playing the game- just work past them. However, if the occasional inconvenience is just not your slice of pie, read some other reviews maybe, and see what you think. Maybe don't get this game if you're prone to frustration at setbacks.

This is one of those games you play through because you saw the critics gave it pretty good reviews and you're interested in the unusual experience you see in preview videos and pictures. And then I finish it and wonder if it's really something I would recommend to another person.  I think the game is good enough that I do recommend it, but it's by no means a hearty, strong recommendation. At $15 I do NOT recommend purchasing this game. The price is too steep for the lack of gameplay hours. There are many other games you can spend $15 and get infinitely more playtime out of than Brothers. Is it worth paying a few bucks to play through it? I suppose so, if you're willing to pay a dollar for an hour of the game--because that's about how long the game is: 3 hours. If you don't want to spend a few dollars on something that short, then walk away from the Steam store page and skip through a Playthrough Video Guide to see what the game is all about.  *Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons* is a puzzle game with an unusual twist on the genre. Instead of the player heavily manipulating the landscape, creating 'new paths' to go through (think Antichamber or Portal), or pushing-and-pulling blocks Zelda-style, this game has you controlling two brothers /at the same time/ and using their combined abilities (mashing the 'Interact' button at everything) to make their way through the landscape. There are conveniently placed horizontal ledges, bumps on the sides of trees for horizontal climbing, ropes, and so forth you use to travel through the game. If I had any one major complaint about the puzzles, it is that I am sick of the amount of horizontal climbing they packed into 3 hours and how frequently my characters would fall because I was too fast or slow mashing the 'interact' button when the characters were ready to jump. This is most likely my own fault, though, and you shouldn't let my inability to press buttons properly influence your view of the game.  The puzzles felt a bit trite to me because it seemed like the developers didn't try to think too far out of the box when they came up with them. 'What puzzles can we design for 2 people? I know! Let's let them help each other climb a ledge slightly too high for them to reach! One of them can get a boost then throw down a rope for the second!' This is more-or-less what a majority of the puzzles in the game are like. There was one level where the brothers tied ropes to their belts and would 'swing' each other from one hand-hold to the next. But, again, this entire level was horizontal climbing, so as cool as the puzzle was I was already getting tired of the obnoxiousness of sideways-ledge-movement. (I am not a fan of this, can you tell?)  The idea of controlling two brothers at once is the reason I purchased the game. I had a good idea of the kinds of puzzles they could utilize in the game with two characters to control (some of which I saw, some of which I didn't). I, unfortunately (and probably stupidly) played the game on a computer keyboard instead of a controller. It took a little getting used to at first, but I got the hang of it pretty well after the first 15 minutes or so. I am disappointed there isn't anything more to 'controlling' them than having them run around and mash the 'interact' button at random things and the obvious puzzles. I would have preferred to see multiple actions from each character that I have to think about and choose from (like combinations between the two) in order to solve the puzzles. Maybe the older brother can punch things and climb better than the little brother? Maybe the younger brother can focus on kicking things and crawling? It would have given a much more interesting element to the game if they each had different skill sets they used in combination to complete puzzles, rather than having me just mash the 'Generically Interact Do-Something-Here' button.   One thing the game had going for it was its art. The character models are pretty 'meh' to me, but the setting of the game was beautifully done. Even the first levels of the village the boys grew up in is very pretty to look at and play through. Each 'part' of the game has a different flavor or level design--from a village, to a 'forge' level, to a 'nighttime'/cemetery design, to a giant's home and navigating the cliffs it was on, and so forth--and each of these levels has wonderful art design. There is a particular moment later in the game when the camera moves to a side-shot of your characters running along a ledge of snow and the auroras, or just a beautiful sky?, are behind them. It's a very pretty moment for the game.   Do I recommend this game? Yes, overall, but not strongly. I found the puzzles to be slightly lackluster and too obvious. The lack of voice acting (they mutter sounds to each other) hurt the game for me rathe than helped it because I would have enjoyed actually hearing the story, since the character art and puzzles weren't great. The art is beautiful, but that's probably not a reason to recommend the game. So is it worth paying $3 for? Yeah, maybe, if you like puzzle games and want to try out something like controlling two characters at a time.

Good god this one hit me hard.  I spent the first ten minutes feeling that Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons was too game-y, that the mechanics were blatant enough to ruin any attempt at atmosphere. That faded about twenty minutes in, by which point the lil' Simlish-speaking brothers were growing near and dear to me, and I felt invested in seeing them through on their adventure. An hour in and the world was charming, kind of like the immersive Scandinavian fantasy realm Skyrim wishes it could offer. An hour and a half, and the charm was struck through with bits and pieces of horror and concern. By the time I finished I was pretty much a screaming, teary-eyed emotional wreck.  Bear in mind that the game's content struck very close to home for me, and I imagine that fact is magnifying the impact tremendously, but even so I adore everything that's been put together here. I've been a fan of Thatgamecompany's work for years, and Starbreeze Studios' Brothers manages to evoke everything Flower or Journey pulled off, but in a dark and haunted way that feels just right for the Scandinavian indie game scene. Do yourself a favor and set aside a good 3-4 hour block so you can enjoy Brothers all in one go.

If you look at my steam library you will see it full of the usual FPS, action games. After playing this game I can say that most modern games are stuck in a rut. I have felt more emotional resonence with this game than I have with far cry 4, assansins creed unity, and call of duty advanced warefare combined. The gameplay is also a delight. Its simple but also connects to the game and story on an emotional level. You play as two brothers, one tied to each joystick. For awhile you fight the controls (eachother) but then everything syncs and you realize that controlling the two brothers mirrors a real like brother relationship. Sometimes you get out of sync but your connected. I know there is a lot of glowing reviews already or this game on steam, but seriesly, put down call of duty, skyrim, far cry, dark souls, whatever your playing and give this game a few hours. It will change your perspective on narrative and gameplay in games and make you want some of the bigger publishers of your favorite franchises to take notice.

Brothers: A Tale of FEELS  It's like those artsy walking simulators (Dear Esther, Gone Home, etc.) except you have to walk and act for two characters instead of one and the designers built puzzles around that. They're simple and easy puzzles, but it's enough to make the game more involving and interesting than the 'artsy walking simulator' genre typically is. It's a short game but the pacing is perfect.

Once again has the Swedish filmmaker Josef Fares done very well with the script for this Starbreeze-game. This was one of the most awesome games of 2013 you probably didn’t play. It is not a difficult game in any way, there you steer two characters simultaneously to solve simple but rewarding puzzles on their journey through a very much story driven sequence of walkthrough scenes. But again, it is because of the lovely story you want to play this game. So go get it!
This game was tons of fun to play! You will be hit with the feels pretty hard though.

This was one of the truest emotional games you could play, and it is definitely not a game for everyone.  The gameplay is unique in terms of control scheme, and this does add some interest to the game, but in all honesty, to me this game was developed primarily to work on the player's emotions, and it does a pretty successful job.  The art style is also wonderful, and the soundtrack suits this type of the game to its core.  Definitely worth a play if you want to experience something different - something more human!

While the gameplay is simplistic and the puzzles are easy, the storytelling is perfect and provides a deep background to its lore. There is no real dialogue between characters and is often done through body language. This way of speaking leaves you filling in their dialogue and understanding what they feel. The art style is great, leaving you awing the rich variety of environments you're in. Overall the game is great for its art and great storytelling and narrative design. It's definitely worth a playthrough!

I honestly have to say that I went into this one a skeptic and came out on the other end a changed man. This game although difficult to explain, (it's somthing you just need to experience), delivers on levels I didn't know were possible for a game. I've been moved by a Mozart Concerto, a Vincint VanGough, and even an epic big screen masterpiece like Braveheart! I have never however, until today, been moved in such a way as to stir my very soul by such as a video game. Don't get me wrong, I've played some exiting titles, (believe me, I've played many) that evoked emotion within me to a degree. None of them even came close to what I experienced in my 4 hour playthrough of Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons! Everything about the game is spectacular from the art to the music and the short but effective narrative. The visuals in this game are breathtaking, often prompting the player to simply stop and look around in order to take it all in. I wanted to be there. I could feel the wind blowing on my neck, smell the refreshing mist of a mountain stream waterfall, feel the warmth of fire, and the bitter chill of a cold dark night. The music was beautiful to say the least. It captured the emotion, surroundings and story of the game in ways I can't begin to describe. The story is simple yet complex in its messages and underlying theme . Even if one can't directly relate to the narrative, you feel for the brothers. You share their pain, their fear, and will even find yourself likley laughing out loud on occasion due to the small moments that make this story so rich and full. As wonderful as the game is, it is not without its small list of faults. First, this game doesn't hold your hand. There are no navigation markers etc. You simply have to explore. This is not difficult however, it just requires some patience. Personally this was not a negative for me, but I can see how it could be for some. Secondly If you need to have a game last for 20 plus hours in order to feel fulfilled then this game may not be for you. I played through in about 4 hours. This was after doing a fair bit of exploring but not being completly thorough. I for one feel that 4 hours was more than enough time to accomplish what it sets out to do. Thirdly, one must be mature enought to understand all the themes present in this masterpiece. In other words, for example, much would likely be lost on a 10 year old playing this. It would depent on the 10 however! In closing, if you want to experiece something beautiful, something a little off the beaten path, then this is it! If you are a skeptic like me, take a leap of faith. I promise, you won't be dissapointed!
This is exactly what I want in a game: a novel idea, good mood setting, and a narrative told and felt through gameplay. Bravo.
A truly great experience to play this game. Don't think any game has ever made me do 'that thing at the end' yet...

Amazing. I'm 43 now and have seen a lot of games, but few have had this level of quality. You can downright feel how much blood, sweat and tears has been put in this title. Whether it's the accurate animations, the picturesque surroundings, or the matching sound & music - nearly every single detail is made with so much love and carefulness, it will sometimes simply take your breath away. Do yourself a favor and take your time to explore what this game has in store for you, especially since people and animals usually react individually to the brothers. I really enjoyed this tale of two sons, right from the touching opening sequence until the remarkable, courageous ending. Besides Diablo III and Torchlight i'ts the best title I played in the last couple of years.  However, there are some minor things worth criticising. First and foremost, and as indicated above, this game is primarily about exploring its beauty. Brothers may be considered an adventure, but if you place importance on brain teasers, you are at the wrong place - the difficulty is mild, to say the least, the solutions are almost always obvious and easy to accomplish. In adition, it's too short - cutting corners, you can replay the game within less than an hour. In single player mode you tend to confuse the controls of the brothers, as you instinctively want to control the one who is currently located on the left side of the screen with the left analog stick, and vice versa. And last but not least, the camera won't rotate in every situation, which is out of all reason, but hey, worse things happen at sea...  The bottom line is: Don't miss this game. It's worth every penny.

This review is gonna be as short and simple as the game is. (badum tss)  You play two brothers who have to go on a great journey to find a cure to save their father. You move the bothers around with the joysticks (one for each brother) and do actions (most likely, grab something) with the triggers.  In my opinion, this game is good but not as much as I expected. The whole journey IS fun and beautifull but simple and short. At the end, there is a very emotive scene but... it doesn't make the game. The emotion and the gorgeous journey are both amazing but the story is so simple that, after playing, you just don't even care anymore.  It is the big difference with this game and any other beautifull and emotive game, there is no mind blowing story or amazing plot twist, it's just nice. You can say that part and that part were great (pretty much all of them were) but the game as a whole is lacking. (The fact that the two characters speak very rarely and in a foreign language probably doesn't help to build a story.) It is literally just Intro -> Go on a journey -> Beautifull -> Beautifull -> Thrilling -> Beautifull -> Emotive -> End  Expect it to be gorgeous and emotive. Expect it to be short and simple.

This is a beautiful, story driven game. The world is breathtaking. The puzzles and gameplay are innovative and fun. It took me about 3 hours to complete and I enjoyed every minute of it. I experienced such a wide array of emotions while playing. Bravo Josef Fares and Starbreeze Studios! I would love to play more like this.

This is a rare game in that the strongest chapter is the third and final one (instead of the first). The ending was not what I expected, but upon reflection made a lot of sense and was well executed. The first and middle acts dragged a little bit, but I can't put my finger on why - I suspect that it is because this game has been recommended to me so many times that I came in with expectations that were too high. The first two chapters were a little run-of-the-mill once I got used to the controls, but the third introduced some really thought-provoking and interesting landscapes and implications that it drew me back in.   The game is about 4 hours long, and stuttered occasionaly on my purchased-in-2012 pretty-standard-dell-laptop. (Review is slightly over three years after purchase). This was not sufficient to prevent me from enjoying and playing the fame, though I admit to being surprised at the problem given that the graphics do not appear to be very high end. The sound is amazing.  Without spoiling too much, Brothers is a tale of two brothers, that you control simultanously. It is a excellent way to force the player to experience the bond that the story is trying to convey. I played with an Xbox 360 controller, which I think helped with the experience, but is not required. (If you get stuck on a certain wall, there seems to be bug when playing with a controller. You need to use the keyboard and press the *up* button to swing high enough. The controller was simply not working with that section).

Gameplay driven games are often perceived as something completely opposite to story driven games. Even when developers find a good balance between gameplay and story telling, these two components usually do not benefit from each other. However... there are rare exceptions...  'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' is an excellent exception. It is a story driven game and its gameplay mechanics are quite unique. But more importantly, the whole is greater then the sum of its parts. Gameplay allows player to 'feel' the story and story itself suggests how game should be played.  Game has everything: 1) Great story which in terms of style reminds the works of Hans Christian Andersen; 2) Great stylized graphics; 3) Amazing soundtrack; 4) Innovative gameplay; 5) Right pacing...  Yes, game is quite short... just a few hours. However, these are several hours where every minute is purposeful. Moreover, one may play this game several times. First time by oneself, second time watching a good friend playing it, etc. After all it is a great 'movie' and a great game in one.  In the end I would like to emphasize once more that gameplay and story benefit from each other so much, that it is impossible to see one without another and there is simply no other game with such organic symbiosis.  Thus, I would like to recommend buying this game and playing it. It totally worth every penny spend!

I wanted to like this game. I wanted there to be a silver lining. There wasn't one.  This game is a tragic tale from start to finish. It does an excellent job of illustrating objectives and foreshadowing the next terrible twist with its art, but there is not much of a positive takeaway from it.  The puzzles were very easy. Not much in the way of creativity there. I feel like the only reason you had to control two characters was to make the ending more meaningful. If you've cleared the game, you know why.  The controls are bearable. It felt alien on a keyboard, and you can't remap controls, but it wasn't a deal breaker. The easy puzzles meant that even if you fumble with the controls, you can clear the game without too much frustration.  I felt the achievements distracted me from the story. I completed one out of twelve, and just knowing the others were there broke my immersion at several points.  Over all it wasn't a bad experience, I just wish it had been less depressing. Every time things were going well, I just knew something bad was around the corner, and I was right. Tragic.

Brothers is a short, story-driven game with beautiful visuals and music, and a powerful ending. It's cute, it's funny, it's mysterious, it's grim, and it's dark, dark, dark. I was particularly impressed with how the story is told entirely without words, at least not in any language the player can understand.  On top of that this game will make you question the world and its lore, as it feels like it only scratched the surface. You do need a controller to have any semblance of functional gameplay, of course. Also, I managed to complete the game in only 4 hours or so, so there's that. Personally, I don't think it really needed to be any longer, but for some people this might be an issue.  On a final note (and without giving too much away), if you're like me and you get a little stuck in the epilogue, just keep this in mind: Don't give up too quickly on using the Big Brother's interaction button. That is all.

Since the controls are not the forte, they couldn't spend too much time making 'hard puzzles', because that would have made players have horrible experiences with them, so they focused on graphics, music and environment design, and they did outstanding job in that regard. Story didn't need to get too complicated because it was only a reason to make the player travel through this beautiful place, so I think devs took the correct choice.
