This game is absolutely fantastic, but it's really difficult to explain why because it's a game you really have to experience yourself (games I have said this about: The Stanley Parable, Journey and Gone Home).   It clocks in at a short 3 hours and feels a lot like a piece of interactive cinema - that's not to say it's got lots of cinematics or anything, it's just full of eye candy and has absolutely no UI. The controls only further the sense you are truly part of the world, as each brother is controlled with an analogue stick (or arrows if you're mad enough to play with KB+M) and a bumper as an action button. This method is used for some pretty nifty puzzle solving but mainly it gives you a distinct feel for each brother.  Okay, so I'm probably losing you here, because at this point you just need to trust me, this control scheme is absolutely genius as it ties into the plot and how you feel about each brother. And that plot is worth experiencing because it is absolutely charming and has real emotional punch to it. Seriously worth playing if you want to experience something interesting and really engaging.

Best singleplayer game I've ever played. A M A Z I N G ! You may be a bit disappointed at first when you try to play it for the first time with a gamepad, as you will find some surprises. First of all, you will have to set up your controller and bind the keys as you wish. Immediateley after, you'll find that the axis left-right for controlling the brothers is inverted, but this is easily changed, you just have to invert it back. But, once you overcome this meaningless problems, you'll find that this is a   great short adventure game  , which can be beaten in around 2-4h, depending on how much you explore. You'll be playing both brothers, who need to cooperate for saving their dad's life. The story is absolutely   breath-taking  , even if it's told without dialogues and without a recognizable language. Music and visuals are intense and help to put yourself in the brothers' shoes. The mechanics are unique, and every single detail was taken into account. Even the characters walk in a determined speed depending on their mood.  Now stop reading and get the game!

A great game. I loved the gameplay, I loved the story.  This game is meant for a controller, and I recommend playing it this way. The control scheme -- left stick for older brother, right stick for younger brother, plus left trigger for older brother's action, and right trigger for younger brother makes for a unique experience. It isn't just a gimick; it is part of the story and feel of the game. It's awkward, and coordinating two brothers should be awkward. But occasionally you get it going right, and it feels great to see the two brothers in tandem.   The story is told without words. The characters speak a made up language, and that is OK. Removing the words lets you focus on the story and emotion. It is part of the charm.   It should be said; this game is short. I beat it about 3 1/2 hours. If that is a problem for you, be warned. Perhaps it is my age, or maybe the fact that I'm a Steam person with way too many games to play, but the short length did not turn me off. In fact, I praise the developers for ending it when they did rather than padding it out, or adding filler levels.   I also had some issues in the beginning. For some reason, the up-down axis for the older brother was reversed on my Logitech wireless gamepad. Fortunately with some help from Google I found a simple edit that I needed to do it a .ini file and was fine.  [Note: When this game was released, a lot was said about it being designed for a dual-thumb stick controller. That is how I played the game, but they have since updated it with better keyboard controls - the older brother is WASD, the younger brother is the arrows. I tried this some, and it works just fine, and does not hinder the experience.]

There's something to be said for a game that conveys so much about its characters and world and so many emotions with no understandable dialogue. This game is fantastic.  It's short enough that it can be played in one dedicated afternoon, which I highly recommend. I played it in chunks, and I think it definitely detracted from the experience. It took some getting used to the gameplay each time I started it back up, but I think it's a really unique way to play a game like this. The puzzles are easy enough to figure out, but still fun enough to keep from getting repetative. There are interactive items in most scenes that don't drive the plot, per se, but give that much more depth into the characters that you'd really be missing out if you ignored them. I loved the soundtrack, as well.   The graphics are beautiful, and this is the kind of world I would spend hours exploring. So many details that only left me wanting to know everything about this world. There are benches in most areas where you can simply sit and observe, and I would recommend doing just that, so you can fully appreciate the love and creativity put into this game.  I highly recommend this game. I think it's worth the full price, but I picked it up on sale.

Holy Mother of God. What a game...  As many others, I started playing without expecting too much. I always liked games where you have a companion on your journeys, though (as ICO, the unfairly bashed Prince of Persia 2008 and, for those old enough to remember it, Bermuda Syndrome, among the others). I almost immediately found myself immersed in the world, and growing fonder with the two main characters.  The game starts with the very sad image of a kid still mourning his dead mother, who died drowning without the kid being able to save her. Without a single spoken word (or at least, without one you can understand) you soon find out that his father is very ill as well, when the kid's brother rushes him out and asks for your help to bring him to a doctor. There you discover that the only way to save him is to find a miracle cure somewhere in the land.  This is the beginning of the game and introduces the mechanics: a ICO-like game where you actually control both characters at the same time, in order to have them proceed together. The young and older brothers have different skills. which you'll have to take into account to solve the puzzles along the way. And the journey itself (and the choice of words here is not random: it DID remind me of Journey at times, especially the gorgeous views and the spectacular soundtrack) is amazing. Funny, exciting, charming, melancholic: every emotion is out there, in a turmoil that won't leave you until the very end.  I won't tell you a single thing of what happens: other reviews do, and I believe they can spoil the experience for you. Just go ahead and play it. It's short, not very hard, but rewarding, and you'll definitely remember it for a long time when it ends.

This is a game to be played! A game that is both simple in design and gameplay, yet heavy on story and control as well. You are two brothers, looking to save their father's life. To do this, they embark on a journey, where the two brothers must be one. One cannot perform without the other. And you don't swap between the two, you control them both AT THE SAME TIME. And you would think that would require amazing skills, but all you need is a controller, and good hand/eye coordination, as well as paying attention. The graphics are very sweet, colorful, and brings worlds to life, as well as what you interact with it. The only thing you need to also keep in mind, is that this game is very short. That 3.1 hours on record is not what I've played so far, it's what took me to beat this game. But unlike games that are more about cinematic simulation like Everyone Goes to the Rapture, Gone Home, and Dear Esther; Brothers is constantly having you do things, with really simple gameplay that requires a good bit of thinking since you are using 2 characters at the same time.  This is a true marvel of simple/complex in almost all aspects. TotalBiscuit once declared this, his game of the year winner, and he considers this, to be favorite game, of all time. Over his former one, which was Deus Ex. I don't think this one trumps my favorite, which is Mass Effect; but if you see this game on sale, get it without thinking twice. You will not regret it.   Pricetag is a bit steep for 3 hours of game, but this offers more than any walking simulator does. Pretty much all of them. But that is my opinion.

Overall Rating: 9/10   This game is an amazing one.  You go on an adventure as two brothers, controlled(at least in my case) with the WASD keys and the arrow keys. You can also play with a controller, if you're into that sorta thing. You go through a series of event and puzzles that you must solve to move on. You must save your sick father by going on a quest to find a mystical liquid.   Story & Chracaters - The story isn't anything new and original. But it isn't always how the story is, but rather how it is told. In this case it is told extremely well. You go through mountains,tundras, and various other landscapes. Each one reinforcing the feelings of being farther away from your home. The brothers work together to solve every puzzle and even disagree at times. They get along or bicker, but they always care. Even without a spoken word of English every message in this game goes through.   Graphics - The graphics of this game are pretty good for the art style. The landscapes are beautiful. Everything is pretty original. There were a few seams I noticed in the world building. They sky in the tundra has one. There was a lot of recylcing of assets. (Which is fine, because that's what you are supposed to do) But it doesn't break any of the immersion.   Mechanics - This is where it really hits you. The mechanics and puzzles were amazing. Some of these puzzles i've never seen before and they were fun to try and solve. Anything from climbing on ledges, slinking through gates only the little brother can do, or pulling big levels only the older brother could. Everything each character could do really sunk in. That's where you know the game has begun to take hold. In the end    you switch mechanics of the younger brother to the older brother to show change and the growing of age with the since the older one died. This was genius, it shoved so much emotion into the control. So extremely well done.    Overall - This game was so good. You get to have a great time and    ride an emotional roller coaster at the end of the game. I knew that ♥♥♥♥♥ was bad as soon as she leaped over that gap like a damn leaping spider.    Even though I have a short playtime on this game and beat it.That doesn't undermine what it was able to accomplish. I would say its worth the money that it is going for now. I am going to go back eventually and do the rest of the small side quests.

(Spoiler-free review) First of all, I'd like to say that if I ever have a 'Are video games art?' discussion with someone, I will bring this game up as a prime example of a video game that is undoubtedly a piece of art.  The basic premise of the game is that you control two characters at once, and use this mechanic to solve the puzzles that the game throws your way. These range from climbing, to operating mechanical devices, to a good variety of more interesting puzzles. The game is about 2.5 - 3.5 hours long, depending on how long it takes you, but the puzzles are all fairly straight-forward.  The art style is one of the prettiest I've seen in a game, managing to look like a moving oil painting. The story, while very simplistic, is conveyed very well, even though there no intelligible dialogue, just vocalizations from the characters.  I played it with a keyboard, and just by judging by how it's clearly an Xbox port, I can only assume it plays much better with a controller. (EDIT: I originally played this without an anti-ghosting keyboard so the controls were kind of messy to work with. If you don't have a mechanical keyboard, I'd recommend using a controller, but it IS doable on a standard rubber dome keyboard, just clunky). It was fairly well optimized - didn't have any crashes, and only had two or three frame drops throughout my play time.  Overall, I'd recommend this game if you enjoy this type of thing - a mostly slow-paced, quite easy but very beautiful and touching puzzle game.

I completed this game in around 3 hours. That being so, 11 pound might seem a trifle steep... But it isn't, let me explain why.   The game is platformer with various puzzles that are all relatively easy to solve. You contrrol two characters: the little brother, and the big brother. You often have to combine the two to negotiate the challenges the landscape poses. For example; can't yank a lever with the little brother? Well you'll need the big brother for that then. Can't fit the big brother through some railings? Thats where you're little bro comes in handy.  Aside from these gameplay features, the game features a charming art style and a folkloric fantasy world which rarely deviates from standard scandinavian fantasy tropes.   So far it seems pretty standard fare, right?   Where this game succeeds is the way it builds a strong emotional connection between the player and the game's protagonists. No mean feat considering our protagonist are speaking a different language (no subtitles are offered either).  It's difficult for me to explain how the game does this so well without depriving you of the pleasure of experiencing it all first hand. All I can say is that this is a game about family and friendship, about adventure and companionship, and about those all too human emotions that require no vehicle of language for translation.  This game is a work of art. A benchmark for all game designers trying to connect their audiences with their creations.  Basically, just pay the 11 quid and thank me later. You won't regret it.

The story is a simple one, two brothers go off to find some special healing stuff to save thier dying father.  The ending... Well, I was little disappointed. But only because I didn't feel any connection to the characters. Maybe because the game is only a couple of hours long, and not very challenging. If there had been more time and longer puzzles to solve to create the bond between the brothers it would have had much more effect. If you look at Shadow Of The Colossus, despite the underlying simplicity of the game I still nearly broke down in tears the first time Agro falls down the ravine. You spend so much time with Agro as a truely reliable and faithful companion it's impossible to feel nothing. This game does nothing like that. You just jog your way between puzzles, completing each one with ease then on to the next. Despite this I will admit that the use of the control scheme to evoke an emotional response is genuinely remakable and remains the best bit of the game.  So to summarise, if you're a casual gamer you'll probably like it more. If you play a lot of games and have mastered games like Portal then you'll find this a doddle, and will be less likely to feel the emotional ending. It would have been better if it were 10 hours or more with more intricate puzzles.  It is a good game, and definitely worth playing, but for me it was too short and a too easy to buy into the story fully.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons; man, where do I begin?   General:  Brothers is the coming of age story of two young boys on a quest to save their sickly, dying father. Having already lost one parent to a tragic accident, the two brothers refuse to let fate run its course, and set out on an adventure to gather an ancient medicine in a land far away.  This game is absolutely beautiful in all the best ways; it's gorgeous, atmospheric, unique, deep and interesting. Brothers takes you on an emotional roller coaster as the boys make their way across the land and encounter challenges and dangers they never expected.  My favorite thing about this game is how you're thrown into a world without an understandable language, and yet the story is told so well that you'll intuitively know what's happening and being said.   Visuals:  The design in this game is what really stands out to me. While I do have a bit of an issue with not being able to scale up the graphics quality, the art direction is still nothing short of a masterpiece. Cinematics and atmospherics are so outstanding that you'll find yourself stopping to take in the world around you more than a handful of time. The levels are designed in a way that you get immersed in the surroundings, and it's a refreshing change from the static design of many other adventure games I've played.   Mechanics:  The gameplay itself is very simple, you control both brothers simultaneously and interact with each other and the world around you to progress through each level. There's the occasional snag here and there, but I didn't run into any problems that couldn't be quickly resolved. While I'm not sure if this game can actually be played with a keyboard, I'd suggest playing with a controller if you have one.  In reality, there are only two main actions, and the rest is done through movement. One action button triggers the little brother, and the other action button causes the big brother to interact. Despite the simplicity of the mechanics, I found that it was more than enough for me to have fun without feeling too limited.   Value and Replayability:  In terms of value, I can't say I would spend the full price for this game just for the simple fact that it's so short. Even constantly pausing and taking screenshots, I only managed to land just under four hours of gameplay. While I deeply enjoyed the story and visual aspect of the game, I'm not sure that warrants the price you're paying for playtime at retail value.  Replayability, well, your milage may vary. Chances are good that I will pick this game up again down the road because of what a work of art I found it to be, but I also understand how it may not be worth a second run for many players. The story's been told, the game's been played, and what's done is done. If you find yourself typically part of that group, then chances are you're not going to find much replay value.   Overall,  I found Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons to be a fantastic story, and while a bit pricey at the full cost, well worth picking up on sale. There's a reason this game has been talked about so widely, and if you like adventure games, this is absolutely one to add to your collection.

I bought this game mistakenly thinking it was a two player co-op that I was going to play with my brother. We both ended up realizing the mistake but sat through and played it together anyway. Both playing our own copy and just generally progressing at the same pace. What sticks out to me about this memory is the total silent respect that came over us when we both got towards the end of the game. Not many games can command attention like this game does, especially at the end, and you will find yourself gazing in awe at the scenery and events that unfold infront of you.

Are you tired of people telling you that Journey is the most emotional game experience ever and one of the best games of all time?   Yes?   Okay, play Brothers, enjoy a game that does something with a gamepad that you will not find elsewhere, feel the feels, then tell those people to shut up and play too.

This game is beautiful and moving. It is fairly short but the brevity adds to to the poignancy.  In essence this is a game that celebrates the concept of family, from happiness and joy to profound sorrow. The familial bond is further reinforced by the concept of team work. I would urge people to play this game on a 360 controller because unlike other games where you need to set 'character A' up on the a pressure pad then switch to take control of 'Character B' as you move her through the door, in this game you are able to control both characters simultaneously using the thumb sticks and running two people in different directions at the same time adds another level of challenge and enjoyment. I fairly certain I lack the coordination to pull this off with keyboard and mouse though.  In a world where films drag on with little thought to plot, with their pointless explosions and shakey-cam and the need to drag out scene beating you over the head with them, you need Brothers: A tale of two sons to remind you the art of story telling is still alive.
Definitely nominating for “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award. Wish the game just keeps going on and on for ever.

I really enjoyed this game. The background graphics were great, and the character graphics were decent enough. Sometimes it was difficult trying to control both characters at the same time, but that could be because I am not used to using controllers. What really made me enjoy this game, however, was the story. While you can't understand a word any of the characters say (due to the fact they are speaking a made up language) you still understand exactly what is being said. The relationship between the two brothers draws you in and makes you a part of the game. I will definately play this game again, and I would recommend it to anyone who likes games with a story that wrings at your heart.
Get it on a sale and the short story is certainly worth it.

A short, but incredibly inticing story-driven game. The game takes you through fantastic areas, each one adding something new to your experience. You, and the titular brothers, will go through sunny villages, deep mountains, ancient battlefields, frozen kingdoms and more, possibly aiding others along the way. At times I caught myself just staring at the background, which is something the game even encourages.  The mechanics and controls are fun, and while a controller is mandatory, it quickly becomes second nature. You control each of the brothers with with a separate analog stick, something I hadn't heard of before this game.  While it only took me about 2 hours to complete entirely, I would still recommend this experience to anyone just looking to get lost in a truly wonderful and inspirational world. The range of emotions it brought to me is something I'm looking forward to replaying some time in the near future.

So the story is simple but it is still very well written. One of the game's flaws is it's puzzles, while they are fun to do they are way to easy. And the talking they don't say very much and repete a lot so it gets annoing after a while. I did run into some buggs where I couldn't go on because of them, but to fix them you just go back to the last check point or restart the chapter which was very annoying, it happened twice to me. Overall this is one of my favorites and deffinatly worth checking out.
